Before the Right Hon. Sir

A star (*) denotes that the prisoners have been previously in custodyâ€”two stars (**) that they have been more than once in custodyâ€”a dagger (â€ ) that they are known to be the associates of bad charactersâ€”the figures after the name in the indictment denote the prisoner's age.
LONDON AND MIDDLESEX CASES.

59.
HENRY EVANS (44)
PLEADED GUILTY to
unlawfully obtaining 10s. and 2s. 6d. from
Walter Philip Besley by false pretences with intent to defraud;
also to attempting to obtain certain moneys from
Walter Philip Besley with intent to defraud.
Twelve previous convictions were proved against him.
Twenty months' hard labour. â€”

(60).
JAMES EDWIN FULKER
, to feloniously marrying
Matilda Elizabeth Snelling his wife being then alive.
One day's imprisonment. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(61).
JOHN FREDERICK BAILEY
to fraudulently converting to his own use Â£13 7s. 10d. received by him to pay to
William Johnson and others the trustees of the
Bolton Abbey Sick Benefit Society. He received a good character. Recommended to mercy by the prosecutors.
One day's imprisonment. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(62).
FREDERICK JOHN COLMER
to feloniously receiving from
William Fletcher orders for the payment of Â£2 and Â£6 15s. by virtue of forged telegrams;
also to causing to be paid to himself orders for the payment of Â£2 and Â£6 15 by virtue of a forged telegram;
also to receiving and obtaining from
William Fletcher certain postal orders amounting to Â£2 7s. by virtue of forged tele
grams;
also to unlawfully and knowingly forging telegrams addressed to
William Fletcher. He received a good character.
Nine months' hard labour. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(63).
WALTER SAUNDERS (20)
to stealing whilst employed under the Post Office, postal packets containing postal orders for 10s., 20s., and 10s., the property of the
Postmaster General.
Nine months' hard labour. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(64).
FRANK LANHAM (34)
to stealing and receiving an order for the payment of Â£220 5s., and within six months stealing another order for Â£179 12s. 6d., the property of
His Majesty the King his master;
also to forging and uttering receipts for Â£179 12s. 6d. and Â£220 5s. with intent to defraud.
Twelve months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

65.
LOUIS DALE WATERMAN (47)
. Unlawfully converting to his own use Â£1 entrusted to him by
Lucie Dresel for the purpose of renewing a bill of exchange.

LUCIE DRESEL . I am the wife of Adolph Dresel of 76 Thicket Road Anerleyâ€”on September 29th I received this letter from the prisonerâ€”I did not know him beforeâ€”in response to that letter I met him outside Mr. Colman's office in Leadenhall Street next day at twelve o'clockâ€”Mr. Colman is my solicitor and manages an estate which I have an interest inâ€”this is the letter: "24 Aldebert Terrace Albert Square Clapham Road September 29th. Dear Madamâ€”I am very sorry to have to inform you that your husband has this evening been taken to the Wandsworth prison for a term of twenty-one days for debt amounting as you will see by the enclosed memorandum to Â£18 5s. 6d. which your husband gave me to hand to you so as to enable you to obtain the amount to get him released. I am well known to your brother and sister-in-law Mr. Villiers Hamilton Pauley and they will tell you who I am. I will do my best to assist you in your time of trouble if you wish me to do so and if you will wire me on receipt of this letter I will keep any appointment at your sister's Mr. Colman's 57 Leadenhall Street to explain matters to him as suggested by your husband to be before being taken away to Wands
worth. We ought to be able to obtain his release. Please wire me before nine o'clock if you require my assistance.â€”Your's faithfully Louis D Waterman. Mrs. Dresel."â€”I did not know my husband had been taken thenâ€”he lived with meâ€”he was sent to prison on a County Court judgment on a billâ€”I went with the prisoner to Mr. Wilkinson a solicitor and asked him to lend me Â£15 on some furnitureâ€”he advised me in a friendly way to go to my brother and explain the matter to himâ€”I went to my brother who is an architect at 25 Victoria Mansions with the prisonerâ€”my brother advised me to write to my sister who is the trustee of the estate and ask her to advance me the Â£15â€”the prisoner suggested that I should advance him Â£4 to renew the bill on which my husband had been taken up and that he thought he could renew the bill which would obtain the release of my husband who had been imprisoned in default of payment of the bill which he had been surety to for a friendâ€”I thought that would be a very good thing so I gave him the Â£4 and I also gave him 5s. for expensesâ€”I thought he was acting as a friendâ€”the amount of the judgment was Â£17 5s. 6d.â€”we parted then and next day I received this letter from him: "September 29th. Dear Madam.â€”I have done every
thing as promised also written governor of prison at Wandsworth copy letter which I enclose. I should show this letter to poor old Mrs. Dresel. Will meet you at twelve o'clock as arranged to-morrow.â€”Yours faithfully LOUIS WATERMAN"â€”this is the enclosure to the governor: "September 29th. Dear Sirâ€”You have a prisoner in your prison for debt the name of Mr. A. Dresel. He was brought to your prison yesterday afternoon about 6.30 o'clock. I have arranged for his immediate release. Will you kindly inform.â€”Yours obediently.
LOUIS D. WATERMAN "â€”old Mrs.

Dresel is my mother-in-lawâ€”she was very ill when this occurredâ€”I had arranged to meet the prisoner at another of my brothers at Buckingham Street Strand and he was to report to me if he had been able to renew the bill and to go with me to obtain my husband's releaseâ€”my brother Devereaux is a public house brokerâ€”the prisoner said he had Smith's clerk who is the money lender who had advanced the money outsideâ€”Smith's clerk did not come in and we went to find him at a sort of public house oppositeâ€”the clerk was not thereâ€”we returned to my brother-in-law's officeâ€”the prisoner said he had spent 30s. of the money on going down to Croydon and settling another action against my husbandâ€”I said that he owed me Â£2 10s. out of the Â£4â€”I do not remember what he said to thatâ€”he left soon afterwards saying he was going up the street to find Smith's clerk and that if I left it to him it would be all rightâ€”he left about 1.30â€”I waited till about 6.30 thinking he would return but he never did so I had to find another Â£4 and with the money which I borrowed from my trustee which had come to the office in the meantime I went down to Wandsworth to release my husbandâ€”I had the second Â£4 in my pocket for housekeeping and I took that instead of paying my billsâ€”I found my husband ill in the infirmaryâ€”I paid the money to the sergeant in the officeâ€”I never heard a word from the prisonerâ€”I wrote to him asking him for my moneyâ€”my brother-in-law told me what to do and I swore an information at the police court and a warrant was issuedâ€”my husband's release was obtained without any assistance from the prisonerâ€”the money was never tendered to me again but somebody came and made out a fictitious account.

Cross-examined. My husband is a mining engineer and an analytical chemistâ€”he did not owe the prisoner Â£1 17s. 6d.â€”I never knew him until this matter occurredâ€”I never knew he was a friend of my husband'sâ€”I heard that my husband borrowed Â£20â€”I do not know if the prisoner borrowed it for my husbandâ€”my husband gave me Â£4â€”he did not say where he got it fromâ€”he said he had had some business transactionsâ€”the prisoner did not show me a letter from my husband in Wandsworth prisonâ€”this memorandum (Produced) was enclosed in the letter of the 28th: "Mr. Waterman will explain all"â€”that is in my husband's writingâ€”there is also on it "Â£17 5s. 6d. and Â£1 footing money"â€”I do not know what that meansâ€”I did not pay any footing moneyâ€”I paid the Â£17 5s. 6d.â€”I thought the Â£4 was for the renewal of the billâ€”I did not understand that a judgment had been obtained against the billâ€”the prisoner was not authorised to go to a number of places to obtain money for meâ€”I heard that he had not been to Smith the money lenderâ€”he said he would have to go to Smith of Croydon to find out where the money was obtained fromâ€”I do think that my husband proposed that I should have a warrant against The prisonerâ€”my brother-in-law and his partner and Mr. Burr said "Lock him up"â€”I went to the prisoner's address but he had leftâ€”I believe he had a flat but there was nobody thereâ€”I said before that I did not wish to go on with the case and that after the summons had been issuedâ€”was quite willing to forgive him for playing me such a dirty trickâ€”I was told that as the proceedings had been started I could not take the
money although the prisoner told me that if I went to the solicitor's office I could have itâ€”I told him that my husband was a bankruptâ€”I did not think the prisoner was helping me or my husband.
Re-examined. I never heard of any tender before the information was laid.

FREDERICK SMITH . I am bailiff for the Croydon County Courtâ€”I arrested Mr. Dresel on September 18thâ€”I went with him to Sydenham to see if he could get the money and then we came to Londonâ€”we went into the Boar's Head in Cannon Streetâ€”the prisoner came inâ€”Dresel knew him and told him how he was situated and that he was in custodyâ€”he then suggested that the prisoner should write or communicate with Mrs. Dresel to try and procure the money to get his releaseâ€”the prisoner said he would do what he couldâ€”I then took Dresel to Wandsworth prisonâ€”there were other actions against him at the Croydon County Courtâ€”the prisoner never came to settle any of them.
The prisoner here stated that he was willing to refund the Â£4 to Mrs. Dresel This was done in Court and the Jury at the Recorder's suggestion returned a verdict of
NOT GUILTY .

66.
ALBERT NORMAN (27)
Robbery with violence with
George Plank upon
James William Bannister and stealing Â£11 18s. his money.

p.hi: said that he considered the evidence of robbery with violence was insufficient and directed the Jury to return a verdict of

div1.p:
NOT GUILTY . This being done the prisoner
PLEADED GUILTY
to an indictment for
assault
ing
James William Bannister. He received a good character.
Nine months' hard labour.

div0.p: NEW COURT.â€”Monday and Tuesday December 14 th and 15 th 1903.

div1.p:
67.
MARIO CAPACCI (28)
, Having in his possession a galvanic battery intended for making counterfeit coin.

p.hi: Prosecuted and the evidence was interpreted.

div1.p:
DOMENICO ESPOSITO . I have lived at 17 Little Gray's Inn Lane Holborn eight yearsâ€”I am a coal dealerâ€”the prisoner lodged with me five ox six weeks in the first floor back room at 2s. 6d. a weekâ€”Siano shared the room with him paying another half crownâ€”on November 7th I was awakened from my first sleep by a knocking at the doorâ€”I went down to the front door and let the police inâ€”I went with them to the prisoner's roomâ€”they searched it and I saw a mattress taken from the bedâ€”a coin fell from the bedâ€”I picked it off the floorâ€”I found a news
paper parcel of coins which the police took from me and openedâ€”they took the prisoner away and came back to search.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. The first time the police came they found the bottles of acid onlyâ€”the police guarded the room and I had not access to itâ€”I found a second coin after the prisoner was arrestedâ€”I do not remember how long the police waited; I was asleep

and my wife got up and had to dressâ€”Siano occupied the room before you cameâ€”the police found the paper parcel under the mattressâ€”Siano was in bed with you when the police cameâ€”when the police knocked at the door you came and asked me who it was and the police said "That gentleman"â€”you opened the doorâ€”I opened the door to the policeâ€”you were inside the house still upâ€”you were undressingâ€”it was 2.30 a.m.â€”when I woke up my wife came and said "There is a gentleman wants to see Mr. Capacci"â€”you were then undressingâ€”I did not put the chain on the door or speak to you about the chainâ€”every night I used to speak to you about the chain because of many valuable things in the house which I did not want to loseâ€”I went to my son because I was afraid and I did not know who it was at the doorâ€”you paid your rent regularly but did not pay me last weekâ€”you never had a fire in the roomâ€”you closed it from inside with' a chainâ€”there was a fastening to fall away outside and inside your doorâ€”there was a lockâ€”it was the front door that was fastened with a chainâ€”your door had a common lockâ€”you and your friend Siano had the keyâ€”the door was locked during the night and sometimes during the dayâ€”it could be locked from outside or insideâ€”I live in the shop and do not know whether the door was opened or fastenedâ€”the wall in which the door was reached part of the way to the ceilingâ€”it was of wood and the rest of brickâ€”only the part that was by the side of the staircase ran up to the ceilingâ€”you slept with Siano.

Re-examined. The prisoner told me he was a photographer when he came to the houseâ€”he said he would take my photograph but he did not take itâ€”he had no studio in the houseâ€”I never went into his room while he was lodging there before November 7th.

LIUGI SIANO . I lived at 17 Little Gray's Inn Lane four or five months with the prisonerâ€”I sell chestnuts in the streetâ€”I saw this small machine in the cupboard and three or four bottles four or five days before the police cameâ€”I did not notice what was on themâ€”I think they were like these produced but I did not noticeâ€”the prisoner said he was a photo
grapherâ€”once he was cursing the weather because he could not take photographsâ€”that was ten or twelve days before the police cameâ€”he paid "The weather is bad otherwise I should have to take the photo-graph of somebody"â€”once he told me to go downstairs because he had to do something which if ho did not do he would lose 5s.â€”that was the lay before the arrestâ€”I was there when the police cameâ€”the prisoner was in bedâ€”I was just going out of the room when I heard the noiseâ€”came in at 10â€”the prisoner came and lay on the bed about 10 to 10.30â€”10 was out of the house when I went to bedâ€”I heard the knocking for twenty to twenty-five minutesâ€”I said to the landlord "What may it be?"â€”the prisoner was then in bedâ€”he had been in bed from ten to fifteen minutesâ€”he went down stairs to do somethingâ€”he came in about 2.35 a.m.
Cross-examined. One could not lock my bedroom door insideâ€”the wall went up to the ceilingâ€”I saw the light at 2.30 and woke upâ€”he prisoner showed me this dagger two or three timesâ€”I told the

Magistrate I had seen the swordâ€”when the police came the prisoner was awakeâ€”he woke up and went out of the roomâ€”he asked who was thereâ€”somebody answered and we went to open the doorâ€”I have never seen any fire in the roomâ€”there was no means of lighting one the chimney was closed-with a piece of cloth behind the bedâ€”I remember buying a packet of cigarettes in the evening and in the morning I put the change in my pocket and three or four days after I found this base shillingâ€”I had no bad shilling; if I had I should have thrown it awayâ€”I went with the landlord to the market and bought a bag of chestnutsâ€”I found I had the bad shilling five or six days after I bought the cigarettes and about seven days before the police cameâ€”when the police were searching the room I gave the shilling to the detectiveâ€”I went to a woman at the shop and told her she had given me a bad shilling after I came back from market the same dayâ€”the proprietor of the chestnuts told me the shilling was bad.

WILLIAM WILLIAMSON (Detective Sergeant) On November 7th I went with Officers Allingham and Purkiss to 17 Little Gray's Inn Lane about 3 a.m.â€”I found the front door fastenedâ€”after knocking some time we were admittedâ€”we were detained from half to three-quarters of an hourâ€”we went to the backroom first floorâ€”the door was fastened from the insideâ€”I knocked several times and received no replyâ€”Sergeant Purkiss put his foot through the door and it openedâ€”we burst it openâ€”we found the prisoner in bedâ€”there was only one bed in the roomâ€”I saw Siano afterwardsâ€”finding the prisoner could not understand I sent for the landlord's daughter who speaks good Englishâ€”I told the prisoner I was a police officer and suspected him of having counterfeit coin and instruments for making the same in his possession and that he would have to dress himself which he didâ€”I directed Purkiss to search the room while I was in charge of the prisonerâ€”Purkiss brought me this battery and the acids and I deemed it my duty to take the prisoner to the police stationâ€”there were acids in the bottles and some in the batteryâ€”some fifteen to twenty Italians assembled and Purkiss accompanied me to the police station leaving Allingham in charge of the roomâ€”the prisoner was charged through an interpreterâ€”he made no reply to the chargeâ€”prior to going back after taking him to the station I searched another house in the vicinity and then returned with Purkiss to 17 Gray's Inn Lane shortly after 6 a.m. and made a complete search for two or three hoursâ€”the top part of the bed was lifted off the bedstead and on the mattress was lying a packet which the landlord picked upâ€”a coin droppedâ€”he picked it upâ€”it is a small room and he was about a yard awayâ€”th packet contained coins wrapped in this paperâ€”in the prisoner's left hand vest pocket Purkiss found four good shillings with plaster of Paris on them wrapped in tissue paperâ€”this piece of glass had an impression of a row of shillings probably half a dozenâ€”it was found in the cupboard with the other things producedâ€”the prisoner gave evidence before the Magistrate and was defended by a solicitor who asked permission for the prisoner to see the glass; the prisoner wetted his thumb and took the impressions off the glass and the Magistrate directed that he should see no more of the
articles producedâ€”I returned to the house and Allingham was relieved by another officerâ€”I examined the room this morningâ€”the top part of the door is matchboard and there is no vacancy above it.

Cross-examined. The partition is not seven feet high; it is an ordinary roomâ€”if Siano had been there he would have been arrestedâ€”Purkiss found this sword under the pillowâ€”we were knocking at the door from half to three-quarters of an hourâ€”there was a padlock on the room door which was used with a staple inside and out.

HARRY PURKISS (Police Sergeant). I was with Williamson and Allingham at 17 Gray's Inn Laneâ€”we found the room fastened inside and had to force the doorâ€”by Williamson's direction I searched the roomâ€”in the cupboard I found this battery with the three bottles of acids and on the shelf these silver ladders about two dozen on which coins are hung to be silvered two pieces of glass one larger than the otherâ€”the larger one had plaster of Paris and impressions of shillings on itâ€”it was handed to the prisoner when he was giving evidence at the police courtâ€”he rubbed out the impression with his fingersâ€”in the cupboard were also this tin of cyanide of potassium this small milling file and the silver sand and this plaster of Paris lying in a paper at the bottom of the cupboard wrapped in an English newspaperâ€”there were also this knife bearing traces of plaster of Paris this tin of grease this small zinc bath empty and the copper wire with marks of silver adhering to it and sandpaperâ€”we searched the other part of the roomâ€”the small wooden table in front of the window was covered with traces of plaster of Parisâ€”the prisoner got up and partly dressedâ€”I searched himâ€”in hip left hand vest pocket I found these four good shillings one dated 1900 wrapped separately in this foreign newspaperâ€”they were very white and plaster of Paris was adhering to themâ€”we took the mattress from the bedâ€”I found this stiletto under the pillow in the scabbardâ€”turning the mattress over on to the floor Esposito picked up a newspaper packet and dropped a coin which he picked up and tried with his teethâ€”I said "What have you there?"â€”he handed me the packet which I openedâ€”it contained these ten counterfeit half crowns with paper between every oneâ€”we searched the house thoroughlyâ€”I was present at each searchâ€”I found nothing relating to photography.

By the COURT for the prisoner. The other officers who visited the house are here and may be witnessesâ€”the room door was fastened by a padlock; there was one staple inside and one outâ€”these two pieces of copper wire were at
tached to the batteryâ€”these four shillings were produced at the police court.
Re-examined. It would not be possible for anyone on the landing to see into the room the partition goes close to the ceiling.

THOMAS ALLINGHAM (21 E.R.) I remained in charge of the room while the prisoner was taken to the station till I was relieved by Long another constable at 6 a.m.â€”no one enteredâ€”I sat at the door on a chairâ€”I was not there when the sergeant came back.
Cross-examined. I was in uniformâ€”Sergeant Williamson was there and three officers I do not know.
JABEZ LONG (53 E.R.) I relieved Allingham at 6 a.m.â€”I remained
until the other officers came and during part of their searchâ€”no one else entered the room while I was in chargeâ€”the landlord was about a foot from the bed when it was stripped.
Cross-examined. I was in uniformâ€”Williamson and Purkiss were in plain clothesâ€”I do not know of any other officer in plain clothes being there.
WILLIAM WILLIAMSON (Re-examined.) There were four officers in plain clothes and two uniform constablesâ€”two were with meâ€”two knew the neighbourhood.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of coin to H.M. Mintâ€”I have seen all these articlesâ€”this is a bichromate battery which is of great intensity for a short timeâ€”I have never had one in a case of this description beforeâ€”it is worked with a solution of bichromate a deposit of sulphuric acidâ€”these ladders are used on the edge of the bottle or jar for holding the coins to take the depositâ€”these four shillings have all been in plaster of Parisâ€”they have been used as pattern piecesâ€”there is nothing in the bath except plaster and silver sandâ€”these ten half crowns are counterfeit four different dates and consequently of four different mouldsâ€”they are not well madeâ€”they are finishedâ€”these acids are used by coiners for battery purposesâ€”the silver is supplied to the battery by the cyanide of potassium and nitrate of silver and saltâ€”this is a solution of chloride of potash and sulphuric acid the other is for working the batteryâ€”it has been tested by a chemistâ€”the file is for milling the edges of the coin.

Cross-examined. The battery is used after the coin is madeâ€”we have these solutions in every coining caseâ€”the copper wire is used for the positive and negative elements in connection with the zincâ€”the plaster of Paris is used for making the moulds and they are generally made with a piece of glassâ€”the sand is used for drying purposes or for polishing the coin and the ammonia for cleaning the metal surfacesâ€”the battery might be used for an electric lamp but I have no personal-knowledge of itâ€”it is not a usual coiner's batteryâ€”I cannot say whether the electric light can bring up photographic negatives; as far as I know I believe the battery is not used for photographic purposesâ€”I have worked on photographic films where no battery is required.
Re-examined. This battery is not commonly used in the process of silvering counterfeit coin but it could be put to that use. (MR. DUNCAN, barrister here appeared to defend the prisoner.)

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence on oath said he was a photographer and a retoucher of negatives and required the chemicals for the preparation of the paper the battery for a light the file for cutting the copper wire for the battery; and that the plaster he found in the cupboard and used for cleaning his toilet glasses and that the small bath was merely a shaving bowl; that he was unaware of any coins having been put under the mattress that the foreign papers he found in the room; and that he rubbed off the impressions from the large glass at the police Court because they were not on it when the police took it.

div1.p: WILLIAM WILLIAMSON (Re-examined.) I found no photographic films
nor lamp but only some old collars socks and things in an old bag which I examined in the room.
MR. DUNCAN submitted that a battery was not a machine under the Statute (See Reg. v. Gover in 9 Cox and Archbold p. 933). The Court overruled the objection.

GUILTY . He was stated to be an associate of coiners.
Five years' penal servitude.

68.
HENRY DREW (52)
Indecently assaulting
Charlotte Gibbons.
NOT GUILTY .

69.
JOHN JEFFERY (40)
JAMES WILSON (30) and
JAMES LOW (29)
Unlawfully having counterfeit coin in their possession with intent to utter it.

ISABELLA HOBBS . I am the wife of Edmund Hobbs who keeps a confec
tioner's shop at 154 Hackney Roadâ€”I was in the shop in the afternoon of December 7th when my girl served Jeffery with 2d. worth of chocolate and brought me this florinâ€”I tried it in the tester and told him it was bad and gave no changeâ€”he said it would get one into troubleâ€”he paid 2d. for the chocolate and went outâ€”Constable Bell came in made a communication to me and I gave him the florinâ€”afterwards the same night the police fetched me to the police station where I saw the three prisoners and picked out Jeffery as the man who had been in the shop in the afternoon.

EDITH RAYNOR . I reside at 46 Lower Templar Road Lower Claptonâ€”I assist Sanders Brothers corn chandlers in their shop at 2 Columbia Roadâ€”on December 7th about 3 p.m. I served Jeffery with an ounce of curry powder at 1 1/2d.â€”he tendered a florinâ€”I gave him 1s. 10 1/2d. changeâ€”he had hardly left the shop when Low came in and inquired about rolled oats but made no purchaseâ€”a constable came in shortly afterwards and said something to me in consequence of which I tried the coin in the tester and found it was badâ€”it has a mark on itâ€”the same afternoon I recognised the two prisoners and another man at the police station as the men who had been in the shop.
Cross-examined by Low. I did not see Wilson in the shop.

GEORGE BELL (88 G.) On the afternoon of December 7th I watched the prisoners and afterwards was with Holland watching themâ€”about 3 p.m. I saw Jeffery go into 154 Hackney Road a confectioner's shop and come out and join the other two prisonersâ€”I went into the shop and Mrs. Hobbs handed me this coin which she had triedâ€”I marked it with a crossâ€”the prisoners went along Columbia Roadâ€”Jeffery went into Sanders' shop and as he was coming out Low went inâ€”they passed each other insideâ€”Wilson was then in Columbia Roadâ€”the prisoners joined togetherâ€”I got the assistance of another officer Hollandâ€”we followed them to the Loggerheads public house in Gascoyne Placeâ€”I told them I should arrest them for uttering counterfeit coin in the Hackney

Road and should search themâ€”they made no replyâ€”on Jeffery I found a shilling and old. in bronze good money: and on Wilson a purse con
taining 9s. in silver two half crowns a florin. 4 1/2d. in bronze good money and a packet of chocolate with the name on it "E. Hobbs 154 Hackney Road"â€”I also found two parcels of metal this is one piece and a packet of sulphate of copper a watch a pair of scissors and six sheets of tissue paperâ€”on Low I found 1s. 6d. in good silver a file and a long table knifeâ€”there is rust and some white stuff on the fileâ€”with the aid of other constables I took them to the stationâ€”in consequence of some
thing that was said I went back to the Loggerheads public house searched and found on the ground in a corner of the bar where Wilson had been standing this bag of curry powder and this match box containing three counterfeit florins in tissue paperâ€”they were charged at the police station with uttering and made no replyâ€”Jeffery gave his correct address 14 1/2 Marlborough Place opposite the Loggerheadsâ€”Wilson said he lived in a lodging house in the Borough but did not know where it was and that he lodged at Rowton House that nightâ€”Low gave his address at 97 Bethnal Green Road which is not correct.

Cross-examined by Jeffery. I found no coin at your placeâ€”I went with a police sergeantâ€”I saw a bed a little table and two chairsâ€”your wife was detained at the police court for inquiries because she was seen to join the prisoners in St. Margaret's Place and was with them in the Loggerheads.
Cross-examined by Low. Not long afterwards we found out from your mother-in-law where you lived.

ALBERT HOLLAND (435 H.) In consequence of a communication received on December 7th I joined Bell and another constable and followed the prisoners into the Loggerheads public houseâ€”I saw Wilson place something behind him as he was standing at the corner of the bar with Low on his rightâ€”it looked like a bagâ€”at the police station I made a communication to Bell and we returned to the public houseâ€”I saw him find this bag where Wilson had been standing.
WILLIAM GUE (480 H.) I was with the other officers at the Loggerheads public houseâ€”I arrested Low and took him to the station.

WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . I am Inspector of coin at His Majesty's Mintâ€”these coins are counterfeitâ€”four out of the five are from one mouldâ€”these acids are used by coiners and the tissue or other paper to preserve the coins.

LUCY KATE WOOD . I am the wife of Charles Wood who keeps the Baxendale public house Columbia Road Bethnal Greenâ€”on November 27th I served Low with a glass of aleâ€”he tendered a shillingâ€”I found it was badâ€”he offered me sixpence which I did not accept but showed the shilling to my husbandâ€”he put it on the counterâ€”I believe Low picked it upâ€”afterwards the police were sent forâ€”I believe these are the broken pieces of the coin.
CHARLES WOOD . I keep the Baxendale public houseâ€”on November 27th I saw Low in the bar and in consequence of a communication I sent

For a constableâ€”I went into the bar to prevent his escapeâ€”I said to him "I have been told you have been trying to pass bad money; let me see it"â€”he refused saying that he knew where he got itâ€”he had the broken pieces in his handâ€”when the constable came I stated in his presence what had occurred and he asked Low if he had any more and proceeded to search him.

JOHN WYNNE (293 H.) I was called to the Baxendale public house on the night of November 27thâ€”I told Low I should search himâ€”he said he had given the coin to Mrs. Wood and that he did not know it was badâ€”I searched himâ€”I only found a good sixpence on himâ€”he had the broken pieces in his handâ€”I asked him for his addressâ€”he said 4 Mann Street Bethnal Greenâ€”I let him go.
Jeffery's statement before the Magistrate: "I plead guilty to uttering them two but not knowing them to be bad money."
Low's defence: "I found the coins in a parcel in London Fields Hackney and did not know they were bad."
GUILTY .

JEFFERY**. and WILSONâ€”
Three years' penal servitude each.
LOW (who received a good character as a soldier)â€”
Six months' hard labour.

70.
THOMAS GLANVILLE otherwise
BILES
PLEADED GUILTY to
obtaining 10s. from
Philip Rutledge Â£1 from
Alice Bullinaria 10s. from
Jesse Barnes and Â£1 from
Walter Emery with intent to defraud;
also to forging and uttering orders for the payment of Â£10 and Â£17 18s. 6d., with intent to defraud having been convicted of felony at Clerkenwell on August 8th 1900.
Four other convictions were proved against him.
Five years' penal servitude. â€”

(71).
HORACE WALTER MATTHEW NOBBS (27)
to feloniously forging and uttering endorsements on three orders for the payment of Â£199 11s. 6d. Â£86 10s. 8d. and Â£329 15s. 5d.;
also to stealing three bankers' cheques for the same amounts the property of the
Bipposu Mines Limited his masters. (See Rex v. Gaster Vol. CXXXVIII page 1179).
Eighteen months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

72.
DILLON WILLOUGHBY (41)
Stealing Â£150 and Â£19 13s. the moneys of
Clem Jenkins.
MR. NEWTON CRANE Prosecuted; MR. C. F. GILL K.C. and MR. DRAKE Defended.
NOT GUILTY .

73.
AUBREY NEWTON (40)
Feloniously marrying
Mary Ethel Pope his wife being alive.

JOHN McCARTHY (Police Inspector.) I arrested the prisoner on Decem
ber 3rd at 9 a.m. in Caledonian Roadâ€”I had no warrantâ€”Sergeant

Buckle was with meâ€”I said "We are police officers and we are going to take you into custody on a charge of having feloniously married one Alary Ethel Pope at St. Saviour's Church Pimlico on January 9th 1902 your first wife Alice Muriel Smith being then and now alive"â€”he said "I have not seen or heard from my wife for sixteen years; she deserted me I did not desert her"â€”I said "You knew in 1896 that she was alive; it was proved in Court by her brother"â€”he said "Yes I remember that"â€”I obtained two certificates at Somerset Houseâ€”I was acting because of complaints from both wives.

EDITH SMITH . I live at 27 Sackville Gardens Hove and am the sister of Alice Muriel Newton formerly Alice Muriel Smith. I was present on April 27th 1887 at St. George's Hanover Square when she was married to the prisonerâ€”she is alive and is in Courtâ€”she lived with the prisoner until sometime in 1888 when my mother was obliged to take her away from him because he was living without paying wherever he went and my mother was obliged to payâ€”they have lived apart eve: sinceâ€”the prisoner pawned the wedding presentsâ€”my sister has partly lived at home since.

HENRY MONTEITH SMITH . I reside at 83 Ermine Road Lewisham and am a clerk to Messrs. Barclay's the bankersâ€”the prisoner's wife is my sisterâ€”in 1896 I made a statement in the prisoner's presence that ray sister was still alive and I also then gave my name and addressâ€”I was not then living at my present address but there was no difficulty in obtaining my addressâ€”I have been in Barclay's Bank for twenty-three yearsâ€”I have not received any letters from the prisoner since 1896â€”a letter addressed to me at the bank would be handed to me without doubt.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I received a letter from you in 1891 but I think not since.

MARY ETHEL POPE . I live at 1 Camelford Street Brighton and am the daughter of the late Colonel Pope of the Connaught Rangersâ€”I first met the prisoner in October 1901â€”I took my mother to a theatre; she nearly fell on the stairs and the prisoner prevented her from being hurtâ€”he asked her for her address and if he might callâ€”he did so and became very friendly with usâ€”he said he had been to see a specialist who told him that he had only a few months to liveâ€”he had pro
posed to my mother for me and he asked me if I could marry him immediately to nurse him in his last months of lifeâ€”he was supposed to have some internal complaintâ€”I married him on January 19th 1902 at St. Saviour's Pimlicoâ€”he described himself as a widower and he told my mother that his wife had died of double pneumonia in the summer of 1901â€”he said she had deserted him shortly after they were married on April 27th 1887â€”he is described in the certificate as a journalist and his father as an Indian judgeâ€”he said that he himself was a war correspondent on the New York Herald and had Â£600 a year that his life was insured for Â£500 payable when ho was forty: he said he was then thirty-eightâ€”I lived with him as his wifeâ€”we went first to Eastbourne

then to Nice and then returned to Londonâ€”we then went to Torquayâ€”had no fortune of my ownâ€”my mother was of fairly comfortable meansâ€”I had an interest in a reversion and I sold it for Â£225 at his request as we had no moneyâ€”that was soon after we left Exeterâ€”the greater portion of that sum was expended in paying his debtsâ€”in the autumn of this year in consequence of what came to my knowledge I took these proceedings on the advice of my solicitor.
Cross-examined. You have never struck me but you have never told me the truth from the day I met you and you concealed everything.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "My first wife deserted me on January 22nd 1888. She was taken away by her mother while I was away on business; I saw her once or twice up to October 2nd 1888; from that date up to the present I never set eyes on her. I corroborate the statement made by my second wife. I know I have done her a cruel wrong."

The prisoner in his defence said that he lost his first appointment as a clerk which was a good one through getting into debt; that his wife left him in consequence; that he always paid his way; that he had never seen his wife since January 22nd 1888 nine months after they were married; that he had written to her and had employed a private detective to find her; that all his letters were returned unopened; that he went to Lewisham to try and find her but could not hear of her; that the money raised by the prosecutrix was only a very small portion of that to which she was entitled; that all he had told her was true; that he was perfectly certain in his own mind that his wife was dead; and that not having seen her for over seven pars he thought he was entitled to think so; that he was a cocaine maniac which had a great deal to do with his not telling the prosecutrix of his career.
GUILTY â€ He then

PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerken
well on June 15th 1896 as Ambrose Winterton. Two other convictions were proved against him one being for forging the death certificate of his wife to obtain money from a society to bury her.
Seven years' penal servi
tude.

74.
ERMAND WILLIAMS LEWIS WARD (33)
PLEADED GUILTY to
obtaining by false pretences Â£1 from
Frederick Beale and Â£1 5s. from
James Marcham;
also to assaulting
William Walsh; having been convicted of felony at the West Ham Police Court on October 26th 1902.
Several other convictions were proved against him.
Twelve months' hard labour. â€”

(75).
JOHN WINTERS (30)
to obtaining certain furniture from
Abraham Rosenberg by false pretences with intent to defraud;
also to stealing certain pianos the property of
Frederick John Rogers and
Alex Holman; having been convicted of felony at this Court on September 9th 1902. Several other convictions were proved against him.
Eighteen months' hard labour. â€”

(76).

to feloniously marrying
Eliza Groves his wife being alive. He received a good character.
Discharged on recognisances. â€”

(77).
WILLIAM RIDGEWAY (17)
to attempting to carnally know
Jane Louisa Brewster a girl under thirteen years of age.
Three months in the Second Division â€”(18).
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(78).
HENRY SMITH (28)
, to stealing a barrow the property of
Gustavus Billings;
also to stealing a door mat the property of
James Chambers having been convicted of felony at St. Mary's Newington on June 12th 1901 in the name of Henry Marler. Four other convictions were proved against him.
Twelve months' hard labour. The Police in the case were commended by the Grand Jury.â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(79).
FOSTER TUPHOLME (38)
to having fraudulently converted to his own use a half sovereign entrusted to him by
Eliza Ellerby Wilson. Several convictions were proved against him
Dis
charged on recognisances. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

(80).
CHARLES SPENCER (26)
to stealing an overcoat belonging to Eric Klinckerfus;
also a sugar basin and other property belonging to
George Mullins;
also a champagne cooler and other articles the property of
James William Paveley having been convicted of felony at this Court on November 18th 1901. Several other convictions were proved against him.
Eighteen months' hard labour. â€”
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.] And

(81).
GEORGE SMITH (27)
to obtaining by false pretences from
Mary Elizabeth Young Â£3 13s. with intent to defraud having been convicted of felony at Weymouth on March 31st 1900 in the name of Charles Henry Smith.
Three months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

82.
DANIEL CRAWFORD (23)
Feloniously wounding
George Stevens with intent to do him grievous bodily harm. The prisoner stated that he was

rs.hi: of unlawfully wounding and the Jury found that verdict.

p.hi:
He received a good character.
Discharged on recognisances.

div1.p:
83.
WILLIAM RANDALL (27)
Attempting to carnally know
Jessie Kaulfuhs a girl under thirteen years of age.

GUILTY .
Four months' hard labour.

84.
CHARLES FISHER (31)
Feloniously breaking and entering the dwelling house of
Charles Homer with intent to steal.

CHARLES HOMER . I reside at 42 Dundonald Road Willesdenâ€”on September Kith I left the house to go for a holiday everything being secureâ€”shortly afterwards I received information and returned on September 20thâ€”I found the panel of the door smashed in and marks of a jemmyâ€”nothing was missing.

GEORGE BALL . I at present live at Brightlingsea Essexâ€”on Sep
tember 14th I had a pony in a field near Mr. Homer's premisesâ€”I went to bring him in about seven o'clock and saw the prisoner leaning against a fenceâ€”I took the pony in and came out again and saw the prisoner leave 42 Dundonald Roadâ€”I went to the door examined it found jemmy marks on it and an entrance forcedâ€”I saw the prisoner going down the street and gave chase and caught hold of him and told him he would be charged with burglaryâ€”he said I had made a mistakeâ€”I said he would have to

go to the stationâ€”he put his hand in his pocket pulled out a jemmy and struck me with it on the arm I had him byâ€”we struggled and both went to the groundâ€”he got awayâ€”he was under my observation about ten minutes.

GEORGE COLE (Detective Sergeant X.) I am stationed at Kilburnâ€”on September 15th I examined Mr. Homer's house and found that an entry had been effected by breaking the panel of the door and inserting the hand drawing back the latchâ€”there were also jemmy marks corresponding to this jemmy (Produced)â€”I saw the prisoner at Willesden Petty Sessions on December 3rd and told him he would be placed with other men for identificationâ€”he said "When did this job happen?"â€”I told him September 14thâ€”he said "I was away hopping then and did not come back till the 18th or 20th"â€”he was placed with eight other men and immediately identified by Mr. Ballâ€”he had a fair chance of being picked out.

EDWARD PITTAWAY (Detective Officer X.) From information I received on November 27th at 4.30 p.m. I was in Pottery Lane and saw the prisoner go into the Queen's Head beerhouseâ€”I got the assistance of two other officers and I went into the bar and said to the prisoner "I want to speak to you"â€”he came up to meâ€”I told him I should arrest him on suspicion for burglary at Kilburnâ€”he said nothing but struck me a violent blow on my ear with his fistâ€”I beckoned to the two other officers who came across the roadâ€”we took him to the Notting Lane Stationâ€”he was very violent there and we had to handcuff himâ€”I called a cab and he said he would kick theâ€”cab to piecesâ€”I sent for an ambulance trapped him down and conveyed him to Harrow Road Police Station where he was chargedâ€”he was not drunk but had been drinking.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. The other two officers I mentioned were about thirty yards from the Queen's Head; not just outside.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I am not guilty and reserve my defence."

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence complained that Sergeant Ayres had been to his mother's place and taken a lot of letters away.

div1.p:
ALBERT AYRES (Detective Sergeant X.) I called on the prisoner's mother and she produced an envelope with an address on it in the name of Whiteâ€”she said "Charles was down in Kent hopping at the time"â€”we com
municated with the fanner in Kent who was said to have employed him and Detective Sergeant Cole received a reply that the farmer failed to identify the prisoner's photo or the name on his books as being there at the timeâ€”Richardson was the farmer's nameâ€”I have not heard of a Mr. Skinner.

MRS. FISHER. I am the prisoner's wifeâ€”he was down in Kent in my maiden name Whiteâ€”we went hopping with Mr. Alfred Skinner on September 1st finished on the 16th and came home on the 17thâ€”a letter was sent us on the 14th to Kent but the solicitor at Harlesden has kept itâ€”I was going to engage him but he wanted too much money.
GUILTY . He then

PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at West
minster on April 12th 1902 in the name of William Jones otherwise Charles Fisher. Eight other convictions wasâ€”proved against him.
Eighteen months' hard labour.

85.
JOHN ROBERT LAWSON
Unlawfully writing and publishing a false and defamatory libel of and concerning
William Joynson Hicks to which he pleaded a justification.
MR. MUIR and MR. BODKIN Prosecuted; and MR. KEMP K.C. and MR. E. WILD Defended.

p.hi:
During the prosecutor's evidence the prisoner withdrew his plea of justifica
tion and

p.rs: Discharged on his own recognisances in Â£500.

div1.p:
86.
WILLIAM SMOOTHY (42) and
ANNIE SMOOTHY (39)
Stealing 1 170 yards of ribbon and a trouser stretcher the property of
Frederick Joseph Hollingsworth and another.

FREDERICK JOSEPH HOLLINGSWORTH . I am one of the firm of Hollings
worth and Matthew shipping agents Barbicanâ€”early this month I had some velvet ribbon to deliver to some clientsâ€”on December 3rd our porter Powell took it to a truck which was standing at the doorâ€”this (Produced) is a portion of itâ€”there were five parcels and something over 1 000 yardsâ€”this (Produced) is the sort of box that it was inâ€”there was a private shipping mark on the wrappers outside the boxes these marks correspond exactly with our invoicesâ€”I have not the slightest doubt that these goods are oursâ€”they went out on December 3rd with the wrappers round them about 11 a.m.â€”I recognise this trouser-stretcherâ€”there was a small ivory label on it but it has been removedâ€”I have two others in my possession part of the same lot with the label on themâ€”the racks which held the label on are still thereâ€”the manufacturer's price for the goods is about Â£14.

EDWARD POWELL . I am employed by Messrs. Hollingsworth and Matthewâ€”on December 3rd about 11 a.m. I had five parcels of goods in boxes delivered to me to put on my hand-trolley and also a trouser stretcherâ€”having put them on the trolley I went back into the office for some other thingsâ€”when I came back I missed the trolleyâ€”I do not know any more about it.

JOHN COLLISON (City Detective Sergeant.) In consequence of informa
tion about 4.1.") p.m. on December 3rd I went to a house in Whitecross Street which is 300 or 400 yards from Barbicanâ€”I went into a room over a barber's shopâ€”I found the prisoners in the front roomâ€”the man was sitting in a chair by the fire the woman was also sitting downâ€”I was with two other constables and I said "We are police officers and are

making inquiries respecting some ribbon which has recently been stolen in the City from a barrow"â€”the man said "I have been ill for two or three weeks; I know nothing about any ribbon"â€”the woman said "We know nothing about it"â€”I said "I have reason to believe you do; I shall search your room do you occupy the back room?"â€”they said "Yes"â€”another detective went into the back room with the woman and I heard her say "You will find it all here; I bought it unknown to my husband off a man"â€”we found the ribbon and the trouser stretcherâ€”I told them they would be taken to the station and charged with feloniously receiving the goods knowing them to be stolenâ€”they were taken to Moor Lane Police Stationâ€”I returned to the room and made a further searchâ€”in the front room I found these two wrappers mixed up with a lot of other paper they have been identified by the prosecutorâ€”I also found large sheets of brown paper which had evidently been wrapped round parcels (Produced) and where the labels had been there is a holeâ€”also in the front room I found a quantity of other goods which have been identified as being the proceeds of similar larceniesâ€”the back room was a sort of lumber room it contained all kinds of things brooches and rings and all kinds of odds and endsâ€”they were not in boxes; they were thrown about the placeâ€”the boxes had all been stripped of their outer covering and the names of the makers had been removedâ€”I found the boxes relating to this charge and the whole of the property reported to have been stolen from the trolley which was found close byâ€”I found a quantity of ties body belts braces new petticoats and forty-two Christmas cards a special order made by Raphael Tuckâ€”at the station the woman said she had bought the petticoat at Caledonian Cattle Market; she had bought four for 10s.â€”she said she was wearing two of themâ€”two were found in the roomâ€”they form part of a dozen which had been stolen.

Cross-examined by William. I know you and your missusâ€”from inquiries I have made I find that you sell jewellery in the streetsâ€”it was found that you had bought some table cloths at Milton Street sale roomâ€”the chenille which was found was not boughtâ€”I believe you have been ill for about two weeksâ€”I was not told at your house that you had not been able to go outâ€”I was told you had been queer for some time.
Cross-examined by Annie. You said you had bought four petticoats for 10s. in the cattle market; their value is 5s.â€”you said you were a dealerâ€”you did not say you bought the ties.
By The COURT. She "did not say where she bought the ties and I did not ask herâ€”at that time we had no charge against her for them.

BENJAMIN LEWIN . I am an assistant to Raphael Tuck and Company Limited publishers and large makers of Christmas cardsâ€”on October 26th a number of Christmas cards were taken to the carriers by our van to be dispatched to Great Yarmouthâ€”they were given to our carman Harry Fordâ€”these two cards (Produced) are specimens of some made by us for somebody in Great Yarmouth they are our own designs; and are copyrights and cannot be made by anybody elseâ€”they were taken by Ford to be delivered.

HARRY FORD . I am a driver to Messrs. Raphael Tuck and Companyâ€”on October 26th I received forty-seven parcels to take to Sutton's yardâ€”I went to Foster's yard firstâ€”my packages were all right when I got there and as far as I know when I leftâ€”I then went to Sutton's in Golden Lane which is about two minutes' walk from Whitecross Streetâ€”I took my van into the yard with meâ€”when I counted the parcels I had only forty-six instead of forty-sevenâ€”I have since ascertained that the parcel which had gone contained Christmas cards.

SAMUEL ALCOCK . I am a partner with Richard Allen of Richard Alien and Company clothing manufacturers of Basinghall Streetâ€”I sold some petticoats to be delivered at Brixton on November 24thâ€”these (Produced) are a part of themâ€”they were given among other things to George Moore our coachman; he had to deliver them at their destination.
Cross-examined by Annie. I did not say at the police court that I had only sufficient stuff to make one petticoat.

GEORGE MOORE . I was coachman to the last witnessâ€”on November 24th I had certain goods given to me to take to Brixtonâ€”these were part of themâ€”I put them in the boot of the 'busâ€”I went to the back of the omnibus and when I returned I missed a parcel.
By The COURT. The petticoats were done up in a bundle and I could see the top oneâ€”this one looks like it.

RICHARD HOAR . I am traveller for Messrs. Alcockâ€”I was with. Moore on November 24th when some goods had to be taken to Brixtonâ€”I was going with themâ€”these petticoats (Produced) were among themâ€”T put them into the "bus myself and two or three minutes afterwards I was told by the coachman that they were gone.

William Smoothy in his defence on oath said that he was a dealer and sold knives scissors combs and jewellery in the street: that he was taken id about a fortnight before December 3rd with bron hit is and violent cold and pains in his heart; that the doctor told him to keep in bed which he did; that the doctor came and saw him in bed and sent him medicine eight or nine times; that on December 3rd he had just got up for his wife to make the bed; that he knew nothing of the goods being in the house or how they came there; that he did not interfere with his wife's business and never asked her what she bought.

Annie Smoothy in her defence on oath said that she bought the ribbon outside the house on December 3rd of a man who looked like the police officer and said he was a traveller and asked if she would buy it which she did for 50s.; that he had the trouser stretcher in a box and said he would make her a present of that; that the petticoats she had bought in the Cattle Market for 10s. about a month ago and did not know they were stolen; that she bought the this also in the Cattle Market on the previous Friday with some Christmas cards and some buttons on cards; that the man who sold them to her was not the man who sold her the ribbon; that she gave the police his description and that he was called "Old Solly"
ROBERT SMOOTHY . I am a costermonger; the prisoner is my brother

â€”he was ill on December 3rd and had been ill for just over a fortnightâ€”I had not been to see himâ€”I do not know if he was in bedâ€”my daughter went to see himâ€”I did not go because I was not friends with his wifeâ€”ho has had bronchitis before.
GUILTY .

WILLIAM SMOOTHY then PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerkenwell on December 7th 1896. Three other convictions were proved against him.
Five years' penal servitude.
ANNIEâ€”
Twelve months hard labour.

87.
JOHN SCOTT (22)
Unlawfully uttering counterfeit coin twice on the same day.

EDWIN JAMES HOWELL . I am a barman for Guest and Company at the King's Head public house Westminster Bridge Roadâ€”on November 9th about 11 p.m. the prisoner came into the bar with another chap who called for drink and paid 2d.â€”then I served them with two penny packets of cigarettes for which the other man tendered this bad florinâ€”I put it in the till and gave him 1s. 10d. changeâ€”there were no other florins in the tillâ€”they went outâ€”when Purdie, the manager took the till we had a conversationâ€”I saw him take out this florin and examine itâ€”about 11.30 the men came into the bar again and I served the prisoner with a pony of bitter price Id.â€”he tendered this second florinâ€”I took it to Purdie who examined it sent for a constable and spoke to meâ€”the prisoner asked me for the change and Purdie said he would give the prisoner in chargeâ€”the other man called for a drink and walked outâ€”the prisoner seemed sober.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I saw you and the other man togetherâ€”you drank together.
Re-examined. They left together and came in the second time together.

HARRY NEWTON MATTHEWS . I am a Bachelor of Surgery at 37 Whitehall Courtâ€”I am attending Walter Purdie who is suffering from pleurisyâ€”he is dangerously ill and unable to come here and give evidence.

JOHN COURSE (Policeman.) I was present at the Westminster Police Court when the charge against the prisoner was gone intoâ€”I heard Walter Purdie the manager of the King's Head give his evidence and the Magistrate ask the prisoner if he wished to cross-examine him or ask him any questionâ€”I do not think he took advantage of it.

WALTER PURDIE'S
deposition read. "I am manager to Henry Guest and Company at the King's Head public house 163 Westminster Bridge Roadâ€”I cleared the-till at 11 p.m. November 9th. About two minutes after I went to it again and found a bad florin in the till the only florin there. I called the last witness's attention to it. About half an hour after the barman brought the second 2s. piece to me. I examined it and found it bad. I then went to the bar where the prisoner and the other

man were standing. The other man walked out directly I showed the 2s. piece to the prisoner. I said to the prisoner "Do you know this is a bad 2s. piece you have tendered. He said. 'No.' I said. 'Well. I shall charge you with tendering it. He said. Well then you will have to prove that I knew it was bad.' A police officer was called in and the prisoner given into custody. Earlier in the evening I found another bad 2s. piece. They all bear the same date and seem to have come out of the same mould. The packet of cigarettes produced bears our firm's name. We only sell them over the counter."

WILLIAM HUGHES (225 L.) About 11.-45 on November 9th Mr. Purdie called me to the King's Head and said that the prisoner and another were uttering counterfeit coinâ€”the prisoner saidâ€”he only changed a 2s. pieceâ€”I searched him and found 1s. in silver and 10d. in bronze and this packet of cigarettes with the name of Henry Guest on itâ€”I took him to the station where lie was chargedâ€”lie said he did not know the florin was bad and that someone had given it to him earlier in the eveningâ€”he was a little the worse for drink.
JOHN WILLIAM WEBSTER . These three florins are counterfeit and from the same mould.

The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate: "I did not know the coin was bad; I know nothing about the other party; I had had a drop of drink when he asked me to change this money; I was not aware it was bad.".

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p: GUILTY .

p.hi:
Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury on account of his youth.
To enter into recognisances.

div1.p:
88.
RICHARD SIDNEY ROBERTS (40)
Unlawfully appropriating Â£7 5s. 6d. to his own use which had been entrusted to him by
Thomas Henry Dorey.

THOMAS HENRY PORKY . I am a builder of Grove Road Brentfordâ€”about April 6th I met the prisoner at the King's Head Actonâ€”I gave him an order for wine amounting to Â£1 16s.â€”he said he was travelling for the Combined Wine Growers and Distillers' Syndicate. Limitedâ€”on May 4th I gave him a second order to the amount of Â£3 3s. and on July 1st a third order to the amount of Â£2 (is. (id.â€”I received the three lots of wine from the syndicateâ€”this is the first invoiceâ€”I sent a cheque three or four days after the first order for the Â£1 16s.â€”I met the prisoner on July 15th in Chiswick I wont with him to the Pack Horse and Talbot Hotelâ€”in conversation I said I wished to give him a cheque for my account on behalf of the companyâ€”he said, "It does not matter"â€”I said "Oh yes. I like to pay for what I drink." and I gave him a cheque for the three amounts. Â£7 5s. 6d. forgetting that I had sent the cheque for the first amountâ€”I asked him whether I should make the cheque payable to the company or to himâ€”he said it did not matter; the cheque was on behalf of the firm and he would send a receipt on behalf of the firmâ€”this is the crossed cheque payable to himâ€”he said he would send it to the company

and the company would send me a receiptâ€”three or four days afterwards I met him and asked him to give me a full receipt on behalf of the firm and ho gave meâ€”this receipt on the printed form producedâ€”I next received a letter from the syndicate who summoned me and I again paid the moneyâ€”I met the prisoner and told him I had received a summons from his com
panyâ€”I said "I shall have to pay"â€”he said Well cannot I pay you Something?"â€”I said "No certainly not: you have summoned me into the County Court; I cannot accept it and I have put the matter into my solicitor's hands"â€”he said he had used the cheque as he was in want.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. I did not meet you first at the Feathers Hotel Ealing but at my brother-in-law's house at Ac tonâ€”I said it was very good whitâ€”I did not say the weather was too warm for champagne when you recommended me still Moselleâ€”I was on my tricycle when I stopped you and asked you for my accountâ€”you did not offer a settlement at the Star and Garter at Kewâ€”I refused to telephone to you because 1 had been summoned.

WALTER SQUIRES . I am landlord of the Crown and Anchor Chiswickâ€”in July I was manager of the Pack Horse and Talbot Chiswickâ€”I changed this cheque for Â£7 5s. 6d. for the prisoner who is a customer of mineâ€”I paid it into my bank I believe on July 15th.

CHRISTOPHER WILLIAM SMITH . I am manager of the Chiswick branch of the London and South-Western Bankâ€”this cheque for Â£7 5s. 6d. was paid in by Mr. Squires and honoured by the London and Provincial Bank.

EDWARD GREEN . I am employed by the Wine Growers' and Distillers' Syndicate 37 Mincing Laneâ€”the prisoner has obtained orders for the firmâ€”ho had no authority to receive paymentâ€”he did not pay Â£7 5s. 6d. into the firm's accountâ€”in consequence of the non-payment of Â£2 2s. and Â£3 3s. the amounts of the two last orders Mr. Dorey was sued by the company.

Cross-examined. We have paid your commission except something under 10s. on two small orders since July 15th when nothing was dueâ€”we always paid your commission on the Monday following the receipt of the order.

BENJAMIN ALLERTON (Detective T.) On November 30th at 12 Cormack Road Twickenham I served the prisoner with a summonsâ€”when I explained it he said "All right I shall be there"â€”he was committed for trial by Mr. Lane after evidence.

p.hi:
The prisoner in his defence said that he never wished to collect the com
pany's money and never asked for it but-being pressed to accept it and being in want he used it intending to repay out of reasonable expectation of good commissions and offered to Mr. Dorey to repay by instalments; and also visited his solicitor for that purpose. He received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .
One month's imprisonment in the Second Division.

89.
HENRY MORRIS (41)
Robbery with violence with two other persons unknown upon
Arthur James Causton and stealing a watch a chain and 4s. in money.

ALFRED MABY (95 G.) I was in the neighbourhood of the New North Road on November 12th about 1.10 a.m.â€”I saw three men coming down Alma Streetâ€”they stopped the prosecutorâ€”I saw him struggle with themâ€”I heard him shout "Take your hands out of my pockets"â€”I saw Morris strike him with his right list in the faceâ€”the blow knocked him downâ€”lie got up and ran awayâ€”I went across and asked the men what they were aboutâ€”the prisoner said "We are all pals; there has been a bit of a row between us"â€”I asked him whether he was going away or what he was going to doâ€”he replied "I shan't go away before I like"â€”I took him into custody and charged him with being drunk and disorderly and assaulting a man unknownâ€”I took him to the station where he was chargedâ€”about 5.30 a.m. I received information in consequence of which I went to the hospital about 7 a.m.â€”I found the prosecutor lying in bed there unconsciousâ€”I went back to the station and informed the officer on duty of it.

Cross-examined. I was twenty to thirty yards off when I saw the men stop the prosecutorâ€”the prisoner was drunkâ€”the prosecutor was in liquor but could walk all rightâ€”there was an electric light opposite.

ARTHUR JAMES CAUSTON . I am a fitter of 209 Glyn Road Homertonâ€”I was going home about 1 a.m. on November 12th when some men stopped me in the New North Roadâ€”the prisoner was oneâ€”one asked me for tobaccoâ€”then I received a blow in the face and fellâ€”before I fell I felt somebody feeling down my pocketsâ€”I had had a drop of drinkâ€”I said loudly "Take your hands out of my pockets"â€”I do not remember any more till I found myself in the hospital the next morning and my watch and chain and 4s. in money gone from my back trousers pocketâ€”I felt the men feeling down my coat firstâ€”I had this small jacket on but not this overcoatâ€”at the hospital I found a scar on my nose one on my temple and one on my jawâ€”the next day I was taken to the station where I picked out the prisoner as the man who had asked me for tobacco and struck me.

Cross-examined. I am not in employmentâ€”when I am I earn Â£2 a weekâ€”I was called out then in the Militia for seven weeks and receiving 14s. a weekâ€”the watch was solid silverâ€”I am singleâ€”I had been to see my sister who keeps a greengrocer's shop in Grenville Street Brunswick Square near the Foundling Hospitalâ€”I left her a little after tenâ€”I had drink at several public housesâ€”I draw my money every dayâ€”I had drawn it that dayâ€”I had half a crown and 2s.â€”I had ten or twelve drinksâ€”I paid out of the money my sister gave meâ€”at the police court I said the prisoner did not seem friendly with the other two men; I do not think he was.

WILLIAM AINGER M.R.C.S. I am house surgeon at the Metropolitan Hospitalâ€”I saw the prosecutor there about 2.45 a.m. on November 12thâ€”I thought he was suffering from the effects of drinkâ€”I found him lying on a couch apparently unconscious; he smelt strongly of liquorâ€”when I went to examine him he was obstreperous moving his head and swinging his arms about so that I found it quite impracticable to examine him

thoroughly but I found a cut on the left side of his head about an inch longâ€”when I started to probe it he began to move his head but from a superficial examination I should say it went to the boneâ€”there was also a clear cut on his nose about an inch long and a bruise on the right side of the jaw which was swollen and slightly discolouredâ€”the wounds might have been caused by falling on the pavementâ€”they were recently inflictedâ€”there must have been considerable violence.

FRANCIS GILBERT (71 G.) I was in Alma Street and heard the shout and went towards itâ€”I saw three men knock the prosecutor downâ€”I crossed the road and claimed the prisonerâ€”the prosecutor sat up and ran in the direction of Bridport Placeâ€”I assisted Maby to take the prisoner to the station.
Cross-examined. I was about 100 yards down the Alma Roadâ€”there was an electric lamp and gas lightâ€”I heard the prosecutor shout "Take your hands out of my pockets."

DANIEL LYNCH (91 G.) I was in Bridport Place and about 140 yards from Alma Street and New North Roadâ€”I found the prosecutor un-consciousâ€”I took him to the police stationâ€”he was examined by the divisional surgeon who ordered his removal to the Metropolitan Hospital.
Cross-examined. I conveyed him to the police station on a barrow which I got from a mews close byâ€”it took about half an hour and then we had to wait for the divisional surgeon.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence on oath said that he was returning home the worse for drink and was stopped by some men but had no recollection of seeing the prosecutor before.

div1.p:
GUILTY . He received a good character.
Twelve months' hard labour.

90.
ROBERT HODGES (24)
Robbery with violence with others unknown upon
Mary Masters and stealing a bag and Â£27 3s. 6d. her property.

p.hi: to the robbery but not to the violence.

div1.p:
MARY MASTERS . I am a widow of 23 Bolingbroke Road West Kensing
ton Parkâ€”I have collected rents for Mrs. Brown for six yearsâ€”on Novem
ber 16th I was in Nelson Street Stepney about 12.30 p.m.â€”it leads into Sidney Street and is parallel with the Commercial Roadâ€”I carry the money in this satchel with a strap across my shoulderâ€”I came from No. 103 to go to 112â€”crossing the road I noticed the prisoner watching me at 13 Sidney Crescent when I was at 112â€”another man was with him but I did not see his faceâ€”I had hardly stepped off the pavement when I heard a signal between a cry and a whistle from where the prisoner was standingâ€”I was immediately seized by the throat from behindâ€”I tried to screamâ€”I signalled to the prisoner with my left hand and thought he was coming to my help but he came in front of me and I felt his blow right in my face on my foreheadâ€”I fell and felt a pressure on my chestâ€”I became unconsciousâ€”when I recovered consciousness I tried to get up but could notâ€”my clothes were cut and torn and my hat was offâ€”my arms dropped to my side I could not use them; I could not get up for

some timeâ€”I was shown my bag at the police stationâ€”there had been Â£23 in it but about Â£4 was missingâ€”on November 23rd I again went to the police station and recognised the prisoner among several othersâ€”after the blow I could hardly speak and the next day could hardly swallow anythingâ€”Dr. Dobson is still attending me.
Cross-examined. Very few people were aboutâ€”I do not remember seeing anyone with the prisoner but everything got very black in front of meâ€”I am certain he is the man.

HARRY TOFFLER . I am a tailor of 31 Sidney Streetâ€”on November 16th I saw the prisoner and three or four men standing outside a shop lower down the streetâ€”as Mrs. Masters came from Nelson Street the prisoner and three or four men crossed the rood; as she put her foot on the step of a door the four men knocked her downâ€”there was a rush of about eight menâ€”when I saw her down I rushed to her assistance and one man struck at me but I turned my head and he missed and ran awayâ€”the prisoner and the others ran awayâ€”one had a lump of iron in his hand and hit me on the cheekâ€”the prisoner took the prosecutrix's bagâ€”they ran into John's Placeâ€”I ran and screamed "Stop thief!" till I could not run furtherâ€”at Crossman's yard I saw a constable stop the prisoner with the bag of money.
Cross-examined. I mentioned the lump of iron at the police station in a statement to the police.

JAMES HAYGREEN (222 H.) I was in Rutland Street heard cries of "Stop thief" and stopped the prisoner at Crossman's yard seeing Toffler and others pursuing himâ€”he had this bag in his right handâ€”at the station he said "If you had not been a faster runner than me I should have got away with it then I should have been all right."

LEONARD DOBSON M.D. I practise at 59 Addison Gardens Kensing
tonâ€”on November 16th Mrs. Masters called at my house about 6 p.m.â€”I found her in a fainting and collapsed condition and very illâ€”I sent her home at once and went to her house shortly afterwardsâ€”she had a con
tusion on the forehead between her eyes caused I think by a blow from the fistâ€”the tissues all round the larynx were swollen she could hardly speak and could swallow with the greatest difficultyâ€”she was suffering from extreme collapse there was hardly any pulseâ€”I sent her to bed at onceâ€”the next day her condition was rather more serious the swelling of the throat continued and on that evening I had great doubts whether tracheotomy would not have been necessary and warned my partner to be present and the instruments readyâ€”she could breathe and swallow with difficulty and her temperature was 102 or 103â€”we were able to avoid that necessityâ€”by means of opium fomentations and stimulants we managed to relieve her from great congestion and the swelling in her throat gradually went downâ€”in two weeks I allowed her to get upâ€”she has had a very serious shock to her nervous system and is still very ill.
GUILTY .**â€ He then

PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at Clerkenwell in February 1902.
Five years' penal servitude and
twenty strokes with the cat.

91.
JOSHUA MACK (47)
Incurring a debt and liability to
Sidney Blofeld to the amount of Â£19 10s. 2d. and obtaining credit by false pretences and fraud.

WILLIAM CHRISTMAS . I live at 93 Hargrove Park Junction Road. N. and am manager to Mr. Sidney Blofeld meat salesman 14 Central Meat Marketâ€”on November 4th the prisoner who was a stranger to me came in and asked the price of meatâ€”we arranged prices and he selected some meatâ€”he said he had got 80 or 100 pigs at home and asked if we sold porkâ€”I said "No unless any customer sent any and if so we did the best we could to sell it for them"â€”he selected meat value Â£19 10s. 2d.â€”he went to the paying-in deskâ€”I did not hear what took placeâ€”he came back and told me he had paid a cheque inâ€”I asked him if he had given referencesâ€”he said "Yes it will be all found perfectly right; there is plenty of money to meet my cheques; and another thing you need not trouble about that as you will be having some pigs in the morning to sell"â€”he went awayâ€”some porters came for the meat and it was taken out and placed on a vanâ€”this is the chequeâ€”it was paid into our bank and returned unpaid on November 6th on which day I saw the prisoner again in the marketâ€”he said he was very sorry the cheque did not go throughâ€”I asked him about the pigsâ€”he said "Well I got home too late and that is the reason you did not get the pigs"â€”he asked me to wait till the following Monday and no doubt he could meet the chequeâ€”it has never been met.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. You came and asked the price of meat I did not touch you on the shoulder and ask what you would buyâ€”you told me about the pigs whilst your meat was being weighed not after you had been to the paying-in deskâ€”I did not understand you to say that you usually attended Bury St. Edmunds and Ipswich Markets every week and would probably buy 60 or 80 pigs and would probably send some to sellâ€”you said you had 80 to 100 at homeâ€”I went out of the shop and saw the meat in your vanâ€”I did not say at the police court that I saw the name on itâ€”I said that a man came back to us and said the name was on the van "J. Mack"â€”I cannot swear whether it was a van or cart.

GEORGE CHRISTIE . I live at 23 Claremont Square N. and am a clerk to Mr. Blofeldâ€”on November 4th the prisoner came to our shopâ€”I booked the weight of the meat he selectedâ€”the value of it was Â£19 10s. 2d.â€”I asked him for the amountâ€”he wrote a cheque and asked me to fill it inâ€”it had "J. Mack "on itâ€”a blot was made on it and I asked him to initial it which he did "J. M." I believeâ€”I handed it to another clerk and asked the prisoner for a referenceâ€”he gave me two Dean and Hatton meat salesmen Central Meat Market and A. Wilson and Sons.
Cross-examined. You tore the cheque out of a book and gave it to me
â€”I wrote this on the counterfoil of the book you took the cheque fromâ€”when we have received the money for the meat the salesman is responsible for the delivery of it.
Re-examined. I do not remember whether I filled in the counterfoil before he tore the cheque out or after.

AARON RAWKINS . I live at 4 South Park Ilford and am a salesman to Mr. Blofieldâ€”on November 4th the prisoner came to the shopâ€”just before he left I went to the cart standing outside and asked him for further references as we were not satisfied with those he had givenâ€”he said he was sorry he could not do so but we should find the cheque all rightâ€”I went back and spoke to Mr. Christmas and then asked the prisoner his addressâ€”he said "North Street and Ripple Road Barking"â€”the next day by instructions I went to North Street Barking and found a shop with no name on itâ€”in the shop I saw a man and had a conversation with himâ€”the next day I think it was I saw Mack at our shop and told him I believe the man whose name was Wagner had said the shop did not belong to the prisoner; it belonged to him Wagnerâ€”I saw some pieces of meat there which had come from our shopâ€”the prisoner said the shop was his the meat was his and that the man was his foreman and he had discharged him.

Cross-examined. After I went to North Street Barking I went to 164 Ripple Road Barking and saw your wife in the shopâ€”I made inquiries of her and said "Has not Mr. Mack got another shop in North Street?"â€”she said "Yes"â€”I can swear that I saw pieces of meat that came from our shopâ€”I can not say that there was more meat there than came from our shopâ€”you never told me that you were going to Bury Marketâ€”I believe you had a cartâ€”I did not look for any name I saw youâ€”I have only seen you in the market on two occasions the day you bought the meat and the following time you came up to see our governorâ€”I believe you told our principal that if he would not pay the cheque in it would be met on the Mondayâ€”he did not say "If you would like to pay this money before 10 o'clock the matter will drop"â€”you made some offer but it was not acceptedâ€”I heard you say you had been disappointed of cash.
Re-examined. The prisoner's name was over the shop in Ripple Roadâ€”I told his wife I had come to make inquiries about the cheque being dishonouredâ€”she said she was aware of that.

HARRY DOVASTON . I am a cashier at the London and South-Western Bank Barking branchâ€”I produce a certified extract of the bank account of J. Mack. 164 Ripple Roadâ€”that shows that the account was opened on September 29th with Â£20; Â£10 was drawn out on October 2nd there were several payments amounting to Â£4115s. 6d. and various cheques to self and tradesmen amounting to Â£42 16s. (6d.â€”when this cheque was presented for payment there was 9s. standing to the credit of the accountâ€”I also produce an extract from the return book which shows cheques dis-honouredâ€”that shows October 24th J. Mack Â£4 7s. 7d. marked "Refer to drawer"; October 31st Â£3 2s. 6d. marked "Not sufficient"; October 31st Â£14 marked "Not sufficient"; November 5th Blofeld the cheque in

question Â£19 10s. 2d. marked "Not sufficient"; November 9th Â£1 10s. marked "Not sufficient"â€”on November 5th there was an amount paid in which brought the credit up to Â£1 19s.; on October 31st it would be Â£1 9s.
Cross-examined. The cheque for Â£4 7s. 7d. was re-presented and metâ€”the cheque for Â£19 10s. 2d. was not re-presented.
Re-examined. If the cheque had been re-presented on the 9th there would not have been enough to meet itâ€”the account was overdrawn Â£4 through a mistake of mine.

EDMUND MORTON HILL . I live at 38 Gaisford Street Kentish Town and am employed by Messrs. Hockley and Twigg. Central Meat Marketâ€”on October 30th the prisoner purchased some meat from us value Â£13 14s. 5d.â€”he paid for it by cheque for Â£14 and drew 5s. 7d. changeâ€”the cheque was paid in to our bank the same day and returned on November 2nd unpaidâ€”I then sent Mr. Herbert Taylor to Barking to make inquiries.

Cross-examined The first time I believe we did not ask you for any reference but you gave a reference in the market of a small amountâ€”I have no recollection of your having had previous dealings with our firmâ€”you told me you attended Bury and Ipswich Markets every week.
Re-examined. I have been eleven years in the firm's employment six at one branch and five at anotherâ€”as far as I recollect I do not know the prisoner at all except for this transaction.

HERBERT TAYLOR . I am a clerk in the employment of Hockley and Twiggâ€”on November 2nd I was sent down to make inquiries about the prisoner but did not see himâ€”I saw him at his shop in Ripple Road on either the 3rd or 4thâ€”I asked him about the Â£14 cheque given to our firmâ€”he said he had had a deal in pigs and that the cheque had been returned and he could not payâ€”I went down to Barking twice.
Cross-examined. You told me you would call up the next morning and see our firm.

FREDERICK CHARLES HUDSON . I live at 21 Cleveland Park Avenue Walthamstow and am in the employment of Woodham and Boddy Central Meat Marketâ€”on October 30th we sold Â£5 2s. 6d. worth of meat to the prisoner which was paid for by cheque which was returned on November 2nd marked "N.S."â€”we wrote to the prisoner at 164 Ripple Road asking for the money but got no reply.
Cross-examined. I know you were served with a summons in the Mayor's Court on the 3rdâ€”some arrangement was made with the solicitorâ€”you have sent one lot of pigs to our firm to sell.
