Re-examined. That was three weeks or a month before we took any cheque from the prisonerâ€”there were five pigs.

TEMPLE COULTHURST . I am a clerk in the prosecutor's employmentâ€”on November 4th I went to the two references given by the prisoner Messrs. Dean and Hatton and Messrs. Wilson and Sons and made in
quiries.
Cross-examined. I was present at the desk when you gave those references.
The prisoner's statement before the Magistrate. "I am not guilty and reserve my defence. I thought there were means in the bank to meet the cheque."

The prisoner in his defence on oath stated that on Monday November 2nd after closing his shop he and his wife counted up the cash in hand which was Â£43 in gold and Â£11 in silver: that his wife said she was going to pay the gold into the bank in the morning the Â£11 in silver being retained by him as he was going to Ipswich Market; that he did not return home till early on Wednesday morning; that he went to Hockley and Twigg's to purchase some meat and asked them to hold the cheque which had been returned over till the following Monday and he would pay it; that it was untrue that he told Christmas he had 80 to 100 pigs; that he gave the cheque in question thinking there would be money in the bank to meet it as his wife had arranged but which she had neglected to do; and that he was innocent of any fraud.

GUILTY .
Three months' imprisonment in the Second Division.

92.
ALICIA HOWE (36)
Feloniously wounding
Albert William Tait with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.
MR. HURRELL Prosecuted; MR. AVORY K.C. and MR. BIRON Defended.

ALBERT WILLIAM TAIT . I live at 44 Brompton Square and am a waiterâ€”I have known the prisoner seven yearsâ€”she lives in the same house and is the tenant of itâ€”on November 14th about 7.30 p.m. I was in the kitchenâ€”I was not soberâ€”there was a little difficulty about a dinner which was being served and I wanted to go out and buy some fresh cheese which caused a dispute with the prisonerâ€”there was a bit of a squabble and I pushed her out of the wayâ€”after that someone knocked me on my backâ€”I did not take much noticeâ€”I went and got the cheese and came back and finished the dinnerâ€”I had a little pain in my back not very muchâ€”that is all I know about it.

Cross-examined by MR. AVORY. The prisoner has lived there for the last five years and has been in the habit of letting out flats to a certain extentâ€”at this time an officer in the Army was occupying the drawing-room floor and it was his dinner I was looking afterâ€”I have acted there as butlerâ€”the prisoner generally has her dinner in the dining room and the things were being got ready in the kitchenâ€”there generally are knives on the kitchen table for cooking purposesâ€”I had been out a good deal of the day on November 14thâ€”I had had a good deal to drinkâ€”I wanted to go out to the grocer's but the prisoner said I was not to go and tried to prevent meâ€”there was a struggle but I did not strike herâ€”I pushed herâ€”I may have said at the police court that I was not prepared to say that I had not struck herâ€”I did not feel the pain in my back during the struggleâ€”I had no trouble in getting outâ€”I got more drink while out returned to the house and finished my work of waiting upon the gentle-man upstairsâ€”I never complained that there was something the matter with my backâ€”the prisoner might have called my attention to the fact: I did not take much noticeâ€”perhaps I was so drunk I do not rememberâ€”I am all right now and there was nothing the matter four days afterâ€”I do not know who has paid the doctor's bill; I have notâ€”he came several

times to see meâ€”I swear I have not been guilty of violence to her on previous occasionsâ€”I was about three years ago taken to the Walton Street Police Station by the policeâ€”the trouble arose over a com-plaint that I had thrown a boot at herâ€”since the present affair happened I have said I was quite sure she never intended to hurt me and that what-ever happened was an accident in the scuffleâ€”I never made a charge against herâ€”the police came to the house and insisted on my going to the police Court.
Re-examined. I really do not know what occurredâ€”in the kitchen.
By The COURT. I did not notice anything for fifteen or twenty minutesâ€”I did not take a knife up nor put one into myselfâ€”there was no one else in the kitchen but the prisoner and myself.

HENRY HAYTER (Police Inspector B.) On November 16th I went to 44 Brompton Square with Sergeant Ferrettâ€”I saw the prisonerâ€”I said "We are police officers; I saw you last night; from information since obtained I shall charge you with wounding a man named Tait with intent to do him grievous bodily harm"â€”she said "Yes I did it; I hope he is dead; he has aggravated me for weeks"â€”I took possession of a jacket and the following day a blood-stained vestâ€”the coat has a cut at the back and there is a corresponding mark in the waistcoatâ€”I went down stairs and saw the prosecutor who was in bed in the basement front roomâ€”I took the prisoner to the station and charged herâ€”she made no reply.

Cross-examined. The cut in the waistcoat is on the left side under the left armâ€”the man made no charge against the prisonerâ€”I now know it was through Lieutenant Thompson that the police were communicated withâ€”on the night in question the prisoner had been drinking and was in such an excited state that she might have said anythingâ€”on the follow-ing night when I saw her she was in a state of excitement.

ALBERT FERRETT (Police Sergeant B.) I went on the Monday with Hayter to 44 Brompton Squareâ€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”she said "He has been the ruin of my life; he and his clique have lived on me for some time; I don't care what happens; I did give him a stick; he has assaulted me over and over again."
Cross-examined. She was in such an excited state that she might have said anything.
Re-examined. I do not say that she was too intoxicated to know what she was saying; she was very excited and might have said any-thing but I think she perfectly understood everything.

FREDERICK VIVIAN THOMPSON . I am a Lieutenant in the Royal Engineers and at present reside at 20 Neville Streetâ€”on the evening of November 5th I went to 44 Brompton Square and took the drawing room floor furnished from the prisonerâ€”I remained till the 15thâ€”on the evening of the 14th about 8.30 I was having my dinner and rang the bell to clear awayâ€”Tait who waited on me and had brought my dinner up did not appear but the prisoner came up instead and took my dinner things awayâ€”I asked where Tait was and she said he had hurt himselfâ€”I asked how and she said he had fallen down stairs and that his shirt was

covered in bloodâ€”she seemed very hystericalâ€”I thought she was making a great fuss about nothingâ€”she said she hoped he would not dieâ€”I said "You need not bother yourself"â€”I thought she was upset because the man had hurt himselfâ€”I asked where he was and was told he had gone out so I thought it was nothing seriousâ€”I said "If there is anything I can do I shall be willing to help"â€”presently he came inâ€”I was called and went downstairsâ€”I found him lying on his bedâ€”he took oft his coat and shirt and I saw a wound on his backâ€”he seemed very dazed; I do do not know whether it was through drink or the woundâ€”the prisoner was drunkâ€”she was sitting on the bedâ€”the man abused her for bringing me down and asked me what she had saidâ€”then he said in effect that the woman had an ungovernable temper and had stuck him in the back with a knifeâ€”I went for a doctor who came and dressed and sewed up the woundâ€”the prisoner fetched some hot waterâ€”the next day I communi
cated with the police.

Cross-examined. While Tait waited on me at my dinner I noticed nothing the matter with himâ€”when the prisoner first spoke to me about him she seemed to be very anxious and asked me to go for a doctor and was very profuse in her thanks afterwards.

FREDERICK CHARLTON . I live at 44 Brompton Square and do house duties for the prisonerâ€”on November 14th I was in the scullery about 7.30 or 8 and heard the prisoner say "Have I done it?"â€”I do not know what it was about and did not see anythingâ€”she then asked me to go and fetch a doctorâ€”I went to do so but saw Tait coming along he had been on an errand and as there did not appear to be anything serious the matter with him I did not fetch a doctorâ€”the prisoner I believe was rather the worse for drinkâ€”Tait did not appear as if he had had much.

Cross-examined. He was as well as he is to-dayâ€”I had been out with him on the Saturday but had not been drinkingâ€”when the prisoner told me to fetch a doctor I knew it was for Tait but I did not know what it was about.

DR. MOSES JOHN ROWLANDS . I live at 235 Knightsbridgeâ€”on November 14th between nine and ten I was called to 44 Brompton Squareâ€”I found Tait lying on a bed in the basementâ€”I examined his back and found a woundâ€”the prisoner was presentâ€”I asked him how it was done and he said it was no business of mineâ€”I asked him if he was going to prosecute and he said "No"â€”I probed the wound and cleaned it as well as I couldâ€”the prisoner was undoubtedly very drunkâ€”I was unable to get anything but a soup tureen to hold some hot waterâ€”the wound went downwards into the muscles of the back from the shoulder-bladeâ€”I put some stitches in and dressed itâ€”I saw the cuts in the jacket and waistcoatâ€”they correspond with the woundâ€”it has healed very well indeedâ€”the stitches were taken out on the fourth day and he is Quite cured.

Cross-examined. I think he was suffering from drink and thought he might have delirium tremensâ€”he was so drunk that when I put the stitches in I did not need to use chloroformâ€”I put them very deep and he would not have allowed it if he had not been so drunk.

The prisoner in her defence on oath stated that she had lived at 44 Brompton Square for about five years; that Tait had acted as butler to her; that on November 14th he was the worse for drink having been out nearly all day; that she objected to his going out spending her money and said he should not go out again and tried to stop him; that there were knives on the table; that he gave her a violent blow and there was a struggle but that she never struck him; that he had assaulted her previously; that when he came back he said there was something the matter with him; and that they were both drunk.
NOT GUILTY .

93.
HARRY TOMKINS (25) and
GEORGE HILLIARD
Having been entrusted by
Thomas Wright with 205 boxes of grapes for a certain pur
pose unlawfully and fraudulently converting the proceeds thereof to their own use.

THOMAS WRIGHT . I am a greengrocer of 58a Kennington Road Lambethâ€”on October 23rd I had 200 odd boxes of grapesâ€”I employed the prisoners to sell the grapes and return to me with the moneyâ€”they took them away on barrowsâ€”they did not returnâ€”on the following Monday the barrows were brought back by three boys with no grapes on themâ€”the grapes cost me Â£6 10s.

Cross-examined by Tomkins. The day before you went out with some grapes in a van and took 6s. 1 1/2d.â€”you came later on and offered me Â£4 but I could not accept it as the matter was then in the hands of the police.

JOHN COURSE (Detective Officer L.) I received information from the prosecutor about October 30thâ€”I made inquiries and kept a look out for the prisonersâ€”I arrested Tomkins on November 24th at 28 Northampton Place Walworth where he livesâ€”I told him he would be charged with stealing 205 boxes of grapesâ€”he said "Where is your warrant?"â€”I produced my warrant card and took him in custodyâ€”he said "All right"â€”on the way to the station he said "Hilliard is responsible; I meant to pay him; I had my half I know that; I will do all I can to make things right."

CHARLES KEYS (Detective Officer L.) I arrested Hilliard on Sunday December 13th at 9 p.m. at Rodney Road Police Stationâ€”he was detained thereâ€”I told him the chargeâ€”he said "Yes I got through part of my money and I was afraid to face the man; that's true"â€”when charged he made no replyâ€”he was committed for trial last Monday morning.

The prisoners' statements before the Magistrate: Tomkins says "I am willing to pay the money my half. My wife is dying confined; I have a wife and four children." Hilliard says "I never stole the grapes; there is no witness here."

Hilliard in his defence on oath stated that he and Tomkins had the grapes; that on the first day they only took Â£1 5s. and that altogether they took Â£39s. 10d.; a large number of the grapes being damaged had to be thrown away; that he said to Tomkins "We look well; this ain't Â£6 10s. to take up; I cant face the man"; and that he always intended to pay the money for them.

GUILTY. Strongly recommended to mercy by the Jury.
They received good characters and on December 17th they were brought up for sentence when it was stated that restitution had been made to the amount of Â£5.
Four days' imprisonment each.

94.
ANTHONY STANLEY ROWE (38)
PLEADED GUILTY to
obtaining from
Lionel George Robinson two cheques for the payment of Â£14 500 and Â£250 by virtue of a forged transfer for 5 000 shares in the Great Fingal Consolidated Limited well knowing the same to be forged;
also to while being the Secretary to the
Great Fingal Consolidated Limited fraudu
lently taking to his own use and benefit three dividend warrants for the payment of Â£3 125 Â£4 606 3s. 8d. and Â£2 022 14s. 1d. the property of the said company;
also to obtaining by false pretences from
Lionel George Robinson Â£14 500 and Â£250 with intent to defraud. It was stated that he had been convicted at this Court on December 16th 1885. (See Vol. CIII., page 107).
Ten years' penal servitude.

95.
AMELIA HOLLIS and
FREDERICK WILLIAM THOMPSON (30)
were charged on the Coroner's inquisition with the manslaughter of
Rose Moore.

p.hi: for the prosecution offered no evidence.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

96.
GEORGE FREDERICK ROBINSON (27)
Feloniously shooting at
Kenneth Graham with intent to murder him.

KENNETH GRAHAM . I am the secretary to the Bank of Englandâ€”on November 24th I went to the waiting room of the Bank about 11 a.m.â€”I saw the prisoner thereâ€”I had never seen him beforeâ€”I said "Mr. Robinson "in a tone of interrogationâ€”he said "Can I see Sir Augustus Prevost?"â€”he is the late governorâ€”I said "No"â€”he said "Can I see Mr. Morley the deputy governor?" he is now really governorâ€”I said "Mr. Morley has not arrived at the Bank; will you tell me what your business is?"â€”he said "I suppose you are in charge"â€”I said "Yes"â€”he then rose to his feetâ€”he was seated when I entered the roomâ€”he handed me this roll of paper (Produced) and said, "If you read that you will see what my business is"â€”I said, "I have no time to read petitions or unfastened rolls"â€”I was standing in the doorway holding the door in my handâ€”the roll was tied up with a bit of black ribbon at one end and a bit of white at the otherâ€”when it was afterwards opened it was found to contain nothing except the words "All of them served"â€”I did not open it at that time; I handed it back to himâ€”I have written things myself but not petitionsâ€”he said "I will read it myself"â€”he put it on the table and then sprang sideways the whole length of the table and putting his hand into his breast pocket drew out a revolverâ€”when I saw that I retired through the doorwayâ€”the last time I saw the revolver

it was pointing in my directionâ€”I closed the door and as I ran into the passage I heard two shots and I heard two more as I went into the lobbyâ€”I sent for the police and then recollecting that there were two other approaches to the corridor where the prisoner was standing I ran round to make them fastâ€”the police arrived and talked to the prisoner through the door and tried to get him to be reasonableâ€”I took them to the other door and then they talked to him in the roomâ€”the hose was then brought up and the prisoner was securedâ€”I afterwards saw two holes in the ceilingâ€”the visible ceiling is a false one made of plaster; one bullet had stuck in the wood work of the real ceiling and the other had fallen back into the false ceilingâ€”this (Produced) is part of the wood work and this the revolverâ€”the piece of wood has a bullet sticking in it now.

GEORGE TOMBIE . I am head waiter at the Bank parlour at the Bank of Englandâ€”after Mr. Graham had gone into the waiting room I was in the passageâ€”I heard talking in the roomâ€”I heard a shot and saw Mr. Graham leave the room and whilst he was coming to the door between the passage and the hall two more shots were fired inside the roomâ€”I went round through another part of the Bank to a lobby and stood where I could see along the passageâ€”I saw the prisoner come out of the waiting room and try to open the door of the passage which had been fastenedâ€”he called out "Come on you cowards you curs"â€”he had a revolver in his right hand thenâ€”I think the police were then on the other side of the doorâ€”the prisoner turned round and saw meâ€”he instantly levelled the revolverâ€”I sprang back and heard a reportâ€”I then went through the lobby to the Bank parlour; before doing so I saw the prisoner coming down the passage in my directionâ€”he came from the lobby into the libraryâ€”I crept into the lobby and up to the door of the library and closed it on him after he had gone inâ€”as I was in the act of closing it he turned roundâ€”he had the revolver in his hand thenâ€”I closed the door quickly; I called for help and remained outside until the police entered and the prisoner was secured.

SAMUEL BACON (City Police Inspector.) On November 24th I was on duty at the Bankâ€”about 11 a.m. I was sent for to the Bank parlourâ€”I went to the door leading into the lobby which was being held by several Bank officialsâ€”I opened it and saw the prisoner standing about eight yards from the doorâ€”I told him to put down the revolver which he was resting on his left armâ€”he was shouting "Come on you curs; come on you cowards"â€”I could not persuade him to put it down so I went to another door which Tombie was holdingâ€”it was locked on the insideâ€”I called upon the prisoner to open itâ€”he said "I will but don't you come in or I will shoot you"â€”I opened the door and saw the revolver pointed at meâ€”I clutched hold of the prisoner by his arm; he swung himself round and jumped out of my grasp; he yelled and ran from the door to the middle of the roomâ€”he said "If you move I will shoot you; send me that tall man; I want that tall man" (Mr. Graham)â€”I asked him to put the revolver down and I would speak to him but he kept on shouting "I want that tall man"â€”he then gradually walked backwards to the fireplace keeping the revolver on his armâ€”the room is a long oneâ€”he

sat down in a chairâ€”after a time I persuaded him to put the revolver down for a minute on the mantelpiece but he still kept on shouting "I want that tail man"â€”I made a move as if to go towards himâ€”he jumped up got hold of the revolver and put it across his arm and said "If you move I will shoot you"â€”I was waiting for the hose to arrive; it came and the first stroke caught him full in the faceâ€”he was so dum
founded that he stooped downâ€”he recovered himself just as Detective Digby and I rushed into the roomâ€”the prisoner jumped into the air and threw the revolver with all his mightâ€”it just missed me and went through the glass of the library bookcaseâ€”I picked it up and rushed at himâ€”as I was doing so he picked up a heavy chairâ€”he lifted it above his head and rushed at two other officers and attempted to deal them a terrific blowâ€”it slightly caught one of the officers on the hand but it practically missed him and caught the edge of the table and broke a piece offâ€”we then secured himâ€”by that time we were nearly drowned by the water from the hoseâ€”I examined the revolver and found five empty cartridge cases in it where the cap had been exploded and one where the cap had not been explodedâ€”that one is filled with candle grease and a little bit of gold on top of itâ€”the powder is still there and it could be firedâ€”it is a six chambered revolverâ€”I went to 80 Westbourne Street Sloane Square where the prisoner livedâ€”I found this box thenâ€”there were originally fifty cartridges in itâ€”I found forty-five in it and there were five cartridge cases and four bullets which had been extractedâ€”they had been apparently worked outâ€”I do not know if any of them had been sealed with gold; the prisoner made a statement which rather led us to believe they wereâ€”we found at his lodgings some papers and docu
ments showing that he had been in the '2nd Canadian Riflesâ€”I also found some letters of character which was given as good and a book containing a statement about propertyâ€”when he was at the station he was rambling about several thingsâ€”I said "Supposing that black ribbon had been taken off that petition first what would have happened?"â€”he said, "He would have had to look out for himself"â€”I said "Suppose the white had been taken off first"â€”he smiled and said "Oh then he would have been all right."

Cross-examined. It is a large-sized ordinary military revolverâ€”it was purchased about two years ago at a pawnbroker's in the Commercial Road; it is a type which was largely used in the late war; it kills at 200 yardsâ€”I did not find any bullets on the prisoner when he was arrested or anything pointing to his belonging to any society or anything of the Kindâ€”he appears to have acted perfectly independently as far as I can find.

HUGH GRIFFITH . L.R.C.P. and L.R.C.S. Edinburgh. I was at the Cloak lane Police Station on November 21thâ€”I examined the prisonerâ€”111 my opinion he was then so insane as not to be responsible for his Actionsâ€”if he had suffered in a hot country on two or three occasions from malarial fever that might affect his mindâ€”hardship in a cold country like Klondyke and then in a hot country like South Africa would be likely to affect his mind as also would the dangers of the late war.

WILLIAM DEWEY BUNCOMBE . M.R.C.S. L.R.C.P. London. On Novem
ber 24th the prisoner was brought to me by the policeâ€”he remained under my observation until December lst when he was taken to the Mansion Houseâ€”from November 24th to December 1st he was insane.
Cross-examined. I entirely agree with Dr. Griffith's evidence.

JAMES SCOTT . I am the medical officer at Brixton Prisonâ€”I have had the prisoner under my observation there since December 2ndâ€”at that time in my opinion he was of unsound mind and has so remained until to-dayâ€”I am of opinion that that unsoundness had existed at least from November 24th.

Cross-examined. I have seen certain letters purporting to come from him to hit family; several attacks of malaria are mentioned in themâ€”if the statements are true the malaria and fever would affect his mind as well as the hardships he has undergoneâ€”I think he will recover but it will take some time.

p.rs: GUILTY but insane at the time and not responsible for his actions.

hi.rs: To be detained during His Majesty's pleasure.

div1.p:
97.
HENRY RICHARD KEMP (49)
Feloniously wounding
Rose Kemp with intent to murder her. Second Count with intent to do her grievous bodily harm.

JAMES DUNWORTH . I am a sanitary inspector to the City of Londonâ€”on December 3rd about 12.45 I was pasting 123 Middlesex Street; I heard a scream; I looked round and saw the prisoner in the doorway with his lift arm round a woman; his right arm was slightly raised and I saw something bright in itâ€”I saw his arm descendâ€”I immediately rushed at him caught him by the back of his neck and threw him into the streetâ€”I then saw this shoemaker's knife (Produced) in his handâ€”I cannot Say how he was holding it when I first saw himâ€”I held him until the arrival of a constableâ€”the woman had received a wound on her left cheek.
Cross-examined by the prisoner. I saw your arm descendâ€”I cannot say if you struck the woman or not.

ROSE KEMP . I am the prisoner's wife and up to a month ago lived with him at St. Stephen's Road Bowâ€”I left him about a fortnight before December 3rd because he would not do any work and was leading me a cruel lifeâ€”we have been married twenty-live years and have had thirteen children; eight are living; the youngest is now threeâ€”I did not have any words with the prisoner when I left himâ€”I went to some friendsâ€”I go out to workâ€”I saw the prisoner once or twice after I left him and before December 3rdâ€”he came up and abused me; he asked for moneyâ€”I asked him what I was to do with the children and he struck meâ€”on December 3rd I was at 123 Middlesex Street; he came and asked me what I was going to do about the childrenâ€”I said I would do my best if he would do his and if he would take one child I would take the otherâ€”I said "You have had money and spent it"â€”he took a knife from his pocket and if it had not been for Inspector Dunworth I should
have been killedâ€”I pushed the prisoner's arm up and screamed and he cut my face with the knife; the mark is on my cheek now.
Cross-examined. You did not ask me to advance you money to save the brokers coming in.

ROSE BROOKS . I am the married daughter of the last witness and the prisoner and live at 35 Palm Streetâ€”on December 3rd between nine and ten o'clock the prisoner came to my house and asked me for some moneyâ€”I said I had not got any but I would try and get it for himâ€”he said he wanted it to save the little ones being turned into the streetâ€”he asked me where my mother wasâ€”I said I did not knowâ€”he said he would take her head clean off her body and he has said so beforeâ€”he is a bootmaker and uses this knife in his trade (Produced)â€”he has told many of us what he intended to do with mother.

HENRY WOODING . I am a shoemakerâ€”the prisoner lives at my houseâ€”on November 30th he came in; he was soberâ€”he said "She is the one I want and I mean to have her"â€”he told me that he meant his wife whom he was living apart fromâ€”I told his wife she had better keep out of his wayâ€”he said he could not keep his children.

LEWIS ROBINSON (903 City.) On December 3rd about 12.45 I was fetched to 123 Middlesex Streetâ€”I found the prisoner in Dunworth's custodyâ€”I saw the prosecutrix bleeding from her left cheekâ€”I saw a knifeâ€”I asked the prisoner why he had done itâ€”he said "For the sake of the children."
Cross-examined. I did not see any blood on the knife.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence said that he went to his wife to ask her for some money to save the children from being turned into the street; that she refused to assist him: that she was carrying on with another man but said that when she got settled down she would take the child Arthur; that he did not remember anything after that as his memory became a failure; that he had no intention of murdering her; that he did not know if he was the cause of the wound on her face because his mind was so agitated he did not know what he was doing; and that he had the knife in his pocket because he was going to use it for his dinner.

div1.p: HENRY WOODING (Re-examined.) I have known the prisoner and his wife for about four yearsâ€”we live in the same houseâ€”she is a sober hard-working woman and has always looked after her childrenâ€”I have never known her to be unfaithful to her husbandâ€”I warned her of what was going to happen because of what the prisoner had said to meâ€”he could have got work if he had liked.
Cross-examined. I have done all I could for you and given you workâ€”you could have got work besides mine the same as other men do.

98.
EVAN DAVIES (36)
Committing wilful and corrupt perjury.
MR. CHARLES MATHEWS and MR. STEPHENSON Prosecuted; MR. W. B. CAMPBELL Defended.

HARRY WICK (211 G.) On October 26th I served a copy of this summons upon the prisoner charging him with selling milk adulterated with 20 per cent of added water; I also served upon him this certificate of adul
teration.
Cross-examined by MR. CAMPBELL. These are the original summonses; copies were served.

ARTHUR CECIL MORRISON . I am second clerk at Worship Street Police Courtâ€”the proceedings under the summons were on November 12th and 13th then there being remands the hearing was on November 20th when the prisoner gave evidence on oath on his own behalfâ€”I took a note of itâ€”he was represented by Mr. Robinson solicitorâ€”towards the end of the examination-in-chief he said "Not to my recollection did I serve any chance customer that afternoon;" that was October 13thâ€”"I did not see the assistant that afternoon"â€”the assistant Mrs. Quinlan was in Court during most of the hearingâ€”the prisoner further said "The following Friday I saw the inspector in Mansford Street; he stopped opposite my barrow and wrote something in a book; I swear I never saw Mr. Weeks that day until the evening; it is not true I leant over the barrow while he divided the sample"â€”he was cross-examined by Mr. Margetts solicitor for the Bethnal Green Borough Council and said "I did not supply chance customers that day; it does not often happen in our neighbour-hood; I swear I did not see Mrs. Quinlan that afternoon or serve her; I swear I did not see Mr. Weeks that afternoon before the evening; I swear there is no truth in the statement that he called on me to stop"â€”the prisoner was convicted and fined.

Cross-examined. He was charged under the Food and Drugs Act and the punishment is summary by a fine of Â£20â€”he was fined Â£20 and Â£5 5s. costsâ€”the notes we take are a complete record of what is saidâ€”we use abbreviationsâ€”I take down the words as carefully as if the prisoner were going to be committed for trialâ€”he speaks English with a slight Welsh accentâ€”he is perhaps not a man of the highest intelligence as a witnessâ€”he was pressed very hard in cross-examination and was got to say "I swear positively I did not see Alice Quinlan that day"â€”the first thing he said was "Not to the best of my recollection did I serve any chance customers that day"â€”then in cross-examination he was asked "Will you swear you did not see any chance customer in Kay Street that day?"â€”when a cross-examining counsel asks "Do you swear you did not serve any chance customers in Kay Street that day?" and the witness' answer is "Yes "I put down "I swear that I did not serve any chance customers in Kay Street that day"â€”they are not the actual living words that come out of the prisoner's mouthâ€”I do my best to take down the effect of question and answer.
Re-examined. In examination in chief he said "I swear I never saw Mr. Weeks that day until the evening"â€”it was not noticeable that he had any difficulty in speaking English.

ALICE QUINLAN . I am marriedâ€”on October 13th I was assisting Mr. Weeks the inspector in his dutiesâ€”I was with him in Kay Street Bethnal Green that afternoon and saw the prisoner there pushing a milk barrow

about three o'clockâ€”the inspector said something to me and I went up to the prisoner and said, "I want a ha'porth of milk please"â€”he gave me the milk but said nothingâ€”I paid him for itâ€”then the inspector came up and told him who he wasâ€”I cannot say exactly what he said but he told him he was going to divide the milkâ€”the prisoner turned round and said "It is milk and water milk and water"â€”the inspector then asked me what I had asked for and I said "A ha'porth of milk"â€”the prisoner started to walk on but the inspector said "Wait a moment"â€”the inspector then went into a gateway and opening his bag took out some bottles and divided the milkâ€”the prisoner did not wait but went onâ€”I saw the name of "E. Davies "on the barrow and also some smaller letters but I do not know what they wereâ€”on the barrow underneath the handle was "Pure milk"â€”we both tried to find the prisoner but could notâ€”I afterwards gave evidence on the hearing of the summons against him for selling adulterated milkâ€”I was in Court when he gave evidenceâ€”I was pointed out to him when the word "assistant" was usedâ€”I have no doubt the prisoner is the man I bought the milk of.

Cross-examined. I bought the milk on October 13th; I gave evidence on the summons I think on November 12thâ€”I do not think I had seen the prisoner before October 13thâ€”it is probable he did not know me before October 13thâ€”I am paid for my services to the inspectorâ€”he asked me to assist himâ€”his wife and I are friendsâ€”I have been doing the work for about five months nowâ€”on the day in question we took eight samplesâ€”when buying the articles I behave in the same way as I do when doing my own errandsâ€”the inspector was a little distance off when I made the purchaseâ€”I bought a sample from another milkman in the Hackney Road at a shop but I did not notice the nameâ€”I have since learnt that the name was Daviesâ€”the inspector divided the milk up into three portions in the shopâ€”he took no other sample of milk in the street that dayâ€”the samples were all at shopsâ€”I know that as soon as the purchase is made by the assistant the inspector has to come upon the scene at once and say who he is and what he is going to doâ€”I say that the inspector called upon the prisoner to stop loud enough to be heardâ€”I should not call it a shoutâ€”I did not notice that the prisoner made so much noise in pushing his barrow that he could not hearâ€”Mr. Weeks did not tell me a complaint about him had been made to the Mayor of Bethnal Green.

JAMES GEORGE WEEKS . I am a sanitary officer to the Bethnal Green Borough Councilâ€”it is part of my duty to take samples of various articles of food under the Food and Drugs Actâ€”the usual practice as to taking samples is someone is got to purchase it for you and when the purchase is completed the inspector appears on the scene and tells the vendor why the purchase is made; then you proceed to divide it into three parts; you seal and mark each part and give the vendor one take one to the public analyst and the third you retain for future comparisonâ€”I have known the prisoner nine monthsâ€”he is a milkman and has a shop at 96 Goldsmith's Row Hackney Road E.â€”his address used to be 17 Goldsmith's Rowâ€”on Tuesday October 13th I was in Kay Street Bethnal Green with Mrs. Quinlan my agent about three o'clockâ€”I saw

the prisoner turn from Hackney Road into Kay Street with a milk barrowâ€”I gave Mrs. Quinlan some instructionsâ€”she went up to the prisoner and purchased some milkâ€”I saw a coin pass between themâ€”I was about thirty yards awayâ€”I came into the street as quickly as possible from the Hackney Road and took the milk from herâ€”I said to the prisoner "I am an inspector appointed under the Sale of Food and Drugs Act for the Borough of Bethnal Green and have purchased this milk for the purpose of analysis by the public analyst"â€”he replied "It is milk and water milk and water"â€”I turned to Mrs. Quinlan and said "Were you told this?"â€”she said "No"â€”I went into the gateway of 9 Kay Street and divided the milk into three partsâ€”the prisoner stopped for a moment looking over the railings and then moved away with his barrowâ€”when he had got a little way I called out "I want you a minute"â€”he replied "All right "but still went onâ€”during this time I was taking the bottles from my bag and dividing the milk upâ€”he stopped and knocked at two doorsâ€”I then continued with the samples marking then and then I saw the prisoner turn into Shoreditchâ€”I went after him but did not catch himâ€”I noticed the name of "E. Davies "on the barrow and "17 Goldsmith's Row"â€”there was some other writing but I could not see what it was I had not sufficient time but at the end on a board was "Pure Milk"â€”after this I obtained other samples from other people and returned to the Town Hall where I reported the circum-stance to the chief inspectorâ€”he advised me to take the third portion to the prisoner's house which I did about 5.15 on the same dayâ€”the prisoner came from a back roomâ€”I said "I've come"â€”the prisoner interrupted me and said "I know nothing of it; take it away" I then said "I've brought the third portion of the sample taken from you this afternoon"â€”I said it was in Kay Streetâ€”I placed it on the counterâ€”he picked the bottle upâ€”I turned and left the shop with my witnessâ€”he followed us and said "I shall throw it into the street" but returned to his shop with the bottle in his handâ€”I got a certificate from the analyst and that was served on the prisonerâ€”I reported the result of the certificate to my Councilâ€”on October 24th I obtained a summons at Worship Street Police Court returnable on November 12thâ€”it went on to the nest day and the prisoner gave evidence on the 20thâ€”it is not true that I said to the prisoner "I'll have you for refusing to sell; if I don't have you in that way I'll have you in another."

Cross-examined. I had a little incident with the prisoner six weeks before this October 13thâ€”my agent went to him and asked for a sample of milk when the prisoner safeguarded himself by saying "It is either milk and water or deficient in cream "; that made it impossible for us to proceed against himâ€”I did not say to him anything like "You are too sharp for me but I'll have you one way if not another"â€”I stood in a doorway on October 13th when my assistant bought the sampleâ€”I did not stay there too long; it would have been fatal if I hadâ€”I have never in all my experience been late in declaring myself to be an inspectorâ€”I have never had a case dismissed by the Magistrate on that groundâ€”I had not to shout to the man to stop the first time but I did when I

was dividing the sampleâ€”it is wrong to suggest that I did not divide the sample in his presenceâ€”when I went to his shop he was apparently angry at seeing me and said "Take it away; I know nothing of it"â€”at the end of the week of October 13th I went to Kay Street and saw two women about it who are witnesses for the prosecutionâ€”I did not tell them what I had come about till I had heard what they had to sayâ€”one said she saw a woman purchase some milk and saw a man come down with a bag and go in the gateway and I said "What did he do?"â€”she said "He took some bottles."
Re-examined. They told me that Davies was the milkman of whom the woman purchased the milk.

MARY ANN BOUTTELL . I am married and live at 10 Kay Streetâ€”Mrs. Hills also lives there and Mrs. Collier oppositeâ€”on Tuesday Octo
ber 13th I was standing against my door with Mrs. Hills about 3 p.m.â€”I saw Mrs. Quinlan in the street and the prisoner with his milk barrowâ€”I have known him seven or eight yearsâ€”I saw her purchase some milk of the prisoner; then Mr. Weeks came up took the jug from her and stood in the gateway of No. 9 which is oppositeâ€”she was about 18 yards from me I could not hear what was saidâ€”Mr. Weeks opened his bag took out some bottles and poured the milk into themâ€”the prisoner was leaning over the gate and looking on; he then walked away down the street with his barrowâ€”Inspector Weeks called after him but he would not stopâ€”he stopped at two doorsâ€”I have never seen anybody take a sample of milk beforeâ€”I was first spoken to by Mr. Weeks on Saturday the 17th.

Cross-examined. My husband is a labourerâ€”I can read but very little and did not sign my name to my depositionâ€”some acrobats with an organ brought me out to my door about half an hour before Mr. Weeks came on the sceneâ€”Mr. Weeks did not shout out after the prisoner loud enough for me to hear what it wasâ€”he called out somethingâ€”I do not know that Kay Street is a roughly paved street or that the prisoner was making a noise with his barrow.
Re-examined. It is covered with flints smoothed over.

SARAH HILLS . I live at 10 Kay Streetâ€”on Tuesday October 13th about 3 p.m. I was at the street door with Mrs. Bouttellâ€”I saw the prisoner; Mrs. Quinlan purchased milk of himâ€”I saw Mr. Weeks come down and take the milk from herâ€”I saw him in the gateway opposite open his bag take some bottles out and pour the milk into themâ€”the prisoner was outsideâ€”he then moved offâ€”I did not hear anythingâ€”I have never seen a sample taken before.

Cross-examined. I saw some acrobats in the street two or three minutes before the inspector cameâ€”I had known the prisoner about seven monthsâ€”he often passes down Kay Street with his barrowâ€”I heard the inspector shout after him but I do not know what he said; it is quite possible the prisoner did not hear himâ€”I think a barrow with milk cans would make a rattling noise in the street.
Re-examined. I am a little deaf.
CHARLOTTE COLLIER . I live at 9 Kay Streetâ€”on Tuesday October

18th I saw the prisoner in Kay Street between 2.55 and 3.5 p.m.â€”he was selling milkâ€”I was looking out of the windowâ€”I saw him deliver some milk at the house opposite and he came across and served another ladyâ€”I saw Mrs. Quinlan buy some from him in the streetâ€”Mr. Weeks then came down the street took the jug from her and said something to the prisoner but I could not hear whatâ€”he then went in at the gate of No. 9 opened his bag took out two or three bottles and put the milk in themâ€”the prisoner looked over the gate to see what ho was doing and then went up the streetâ€”Mr. Weeks said something to him but I do not know whatâ€”I saw Mrs. Hill and Mrs. Bouttell standing at their door opposite.

Cross-examined. Mrs. Double is my landlady at 9 Kay Streetâ€”I was on perfectly friendly terms with her on October 13thâ€”I had never spoken to Mrs. Hill or Mrs. Bouttell beforeâ€”I spoke to them about it when I was called at the police courtâ€”I did not say anything to my landlady about it; I did not think it was necessary.

WILLIAM ROWSELL . I am sanitary inspector to the Bethnal Green Borough Councilâ€”on October 13th in the evening I went with Mr. Weeks to the prisoner's premises. 96 Goldsmith's Rowâ€”we went into the shopâ€”he came in and Mr. Weeks told him he had come with the third portion of the milk he had taken from him that afternoon and he put it on the counterâ€”he said "I know nothing of it; take it away; I shall throw it in the street"â€”he then followed us into the street.

Cross-examined. I was not the inspector on the previous occasion when a sample was taken from the prisonerâ€”I believe he knows me as an inspect
torâ€”when we entered his shop he would know who I wasâ€”he was angry and excited.
WILLIAM ALEXANDER CORODINE . I am an assistant surveyor to the Bethnal Green Borough Councilâ€”I made this plan of Kay Street and the adjoining streetsâ€”it is correct to scale.
Cross-examined. Anybody walking down Kay Street to Goldsmith's Row would only have to turn the corner to get to the prisoner's shopâ€”Kay Street is about 330 yards long.

DR. JOHN EVANS . I have known the prisoner ever since my boyhoodâ€”he lived for about fifteen years in Wales before he came to Londonâ€”he bears the character of a very respectable citizenâ€”I have been told he is a dairyman in a small way of business.

Cross-examined by MR. MATHEWS. I do not know that he has been convicted and fined upon January 13th 1899 for selling adulterated butter; it may be soâ€”I do not know of his having been convicted and fined on March 13th 1903 of selling adulterated milkâ€”I have not met him this yearâ€”my acquaintance with him dates back some years and of late has not been of a very close characterâ€”I heard a few days ago of the last conviction.
Re-examined. I knew he was a retail trader.
JOHN WILLIAMS . I am in the dairy trade at Blandford Street W.
â€”I have known the prisoner from boyhoodâ€”he has borne a very good character.

Cross-examined. I mean a very good character as a manâ€”he is also a straightforward man as a traderâ€”I know that his business has been carried on in his wife's nameâ€”I did not know that that was owing to his failureâ€”I did not know that ho was convicted in January 1897 of selling adulterated milk but I did know that some years ago he was convicted of itâ€”I knew he was convicted in March 1903 of selling adulterated milkâ€”that would not make any difference in my opinion of him as being a highly conscientious trader as he is only a small dealer and does not have a direct supply.

Re-examined. I heard that he pleaded guilty in 1903 to selling adul
terated milkâ€”I have never heard of his committing perjury to resist such an action.

THOMAS PENFOLD . I am a butcher at 100 Goldsmith's Row Hackney Road of twenty-seven years' standingâ€”I know the prisoner personally and always as a thoroughly respectable manâ€”the convictions against him I did not know about or else I should not have come hereâ€”I have been a customer of his and the goods he has supplied to me have been as I thought of a proper standard.
By The COURT. I have never heard anything against his character till to-day.

REV. WILLIAM DAVIES . I serve a church in Hornsey Roadâ€”I have known the prisoner four or five yearsâ€”he has always enjoyed a very high reputation as a man of the highest integrity and of excellent and moral conduct.

Cross-examined. I had not heard of these convictions till to-dayâ€”the milk conviction would not alter my opinion very much because I find that the most respectable tradesmen in London are fined for the same thing because a man on receiving milk cannot be certain as to its characterâ€”my opinion would be affected if it were proved that he tampered with the milk himself.
Re-examined. I should like to know the circumstances of the case before I altered my opinion of his general integrity or character.
NOT GUILTY .

99.
GEORGINA HENRIETTA SPARKS (48)
PLEADED GUILTY to
uttering certain deeds purporting to be leases of two dwelling houses at Margate with intent to defraud.
Judgment respited.

div0.p: OLD COURT Friday Saturday and Monday December 18th, 19th and 21st 1903.

div1.p:
100.
JOHN JOHNSON (60)
Stealing Â£86 the moneys of
Williams. Deacons Limited.

(The prisoner stated that he was
GUILTY of an attempt to steal.)

HARRY WRIGHT . I am a joiner of 37 St. Paul's Road Kennington Parkâ€”on November 20th I was employed on the doors of Williams Deacons' Bank at Mincing Lane at 2.30â€”I saw the prisoner come into the bankâ€”he looked through the glass door and when the cashier passed through he went down the steps and came up again through the door and round to the pass book department; he came round again took a piece of paper and gave it to the cashier and as he turned to speak to another cashier he put this stick through the bars and pulled this packet of notes forward placed them in his coat pocket and made towards the doorâ€”as he put his hand on the door handle I came out of the little box I was fixing up for the commissionaire; he knocked my arm down and banged my head against the doorâ€”I called for help and the commissionaire came and took him to the waiting roomâ€”the police were called in and he was taken into custody.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. Several people were in the bankâ€”I have no doubt that you asked for change for a Â£5 noteâ€”as the cashier turned his back you walked towards other cashiersâ€”I remember a pocket book being found on the counterâ€”I caught hold of you by your arms and held you down below the counterâ€”I did not see you throw the packet over the counterâ€”I did not see your wallet foundâ€”I heard it was found on the counterâ€”I went into the waiting room a few minutes after you.
Re-examined. The door the prisoner had his hand on the handle of is six or seven feet from the counter.

ALEXANDER SEPTIMUS HOLDING . I am a cashier at Williams Deacons' Bankâ€”the prisoner came there on November 20th handed me a Â£5 note and asked me to cash it for himâ€”I said "Are you a customer?"â€”he said "Yes"â€”he gave the name of G. Martinâ€”we had no customer of that nameâ€”as I went to look for the name I heard a scuffleâ€”packets were on the counter containing bank notesâ€”I was at the counter workingâ€”this packet contained Â£85 in notes and Â£1 in goldâ€”it was handed me by Izard another clerkâ€”I saw the prisoner in custody.

FRANCIS WILLIAM IZARD . I am a ledger clerk at Williams Deacons' Bankâ€”on November 20th I heard a disturbanceâ€”I went round to the entrance and saw the prisoner held by Wrightâ€”I saw a packet on the floor on the public side about mid way between the door and the counterâ€”I kicked it up and handed it to the cashierâ€”it was sealed up and contained a remittance from a customer.

LEWIS HASLER (City Police Sergeant.) I was called to Williams Deacons' Bank on November 20th where I found Wright holding the prisonerâ€”Wright told me what had occurredâ€”I told the prisoner I should take him into custody and that he would be charged with stealing the notesâ€”he made no replyâ€”he was taken to the station and the charge read overâ€”he made no replyâ€”I searched him and found 1s. 10d. in cash two cheques on the Birkbeck Bank in the name of George Belper and some credit slips and counterfoils.
The prisoner in his defence said that he went into the bank to change a Â£5

p.hi: note with the intention of backing a horse but being short of money he was tempted and tried to steal the packet but was under the impression that he knocked it on the other side of the counter and that it was his own pocket book he tried to put in his pocket but that he never had the notes in his hand.

div1.p: GUILTY .

He then
PLEADED GUILTY ** to a conviction of felony on September 24th, 1900 at Marylebone Police Court.
Eighteen months' hard labour.

101.
ARTHUR HENRY BINT (43)
Unlawfully obtaining from
Arthur Tyrrell and others Â£4 5s. and other sums by false pretences.
MR. ABEL THOMAS K.C. M.P. and MR. BIRON Prosecuted; MR. MUIR and MR. MURPHY Defended.

WILLIAM JOHN BENNETT . I am managing clerk to the Acme Wood Flooring Company Limitedâ€”I live at Victoria Park Road Hackneyâ€”I have been in the company's employ about seven yearsâ€”Bint came into that employment about August 1902 and remained till these proceedingsâ€”he was travelling foremanâ€”his duties were to visit the different jobs to estimate to measure up work to see that the right number of men were on the work and the wages agreed upon and to act as a check on the men working in the businessâ€”there was absolutely no other checkâ€”it was his duty to report the number of men employed which is an important factorâ€”his wages were Â£3 a week and all out of pocket expenses including hotel and railway faresâ€”Italians and English are employedâ€”that matter was frequently discussed between me and the prisoner who contended that it was preferable to employ Italians as they were industrious brought out better work and were more to be depended on and the decision was practically left to himâ€”in some cases the work was paid for by piece work and in some by the hourâ€”a local or working foreman who is under the prisoner looks after the job in each place where the work isâ€”we appoint himâ€”the prisoner is consulted and his advice takenâ€”the working foreman at the end of each week makes out the wages sheet which shows the number of hours the men work the number of men employed and the price per hourâ€”these are sent to the head office on the Thursday of each week and the money is sent down to the foreman of the job in a registered letter in bank notes and postal ordersâ€”the foreman is very often appointed by the prisonerâ€”we never appoint a foreman without consulting the prisonerâ€”in consequence of discoveries made in October an Italian foreman named Cairo was prosecuted at Sheffield at the police court on October 21st and was committed for trial at the Sessions on October 24th for attempt-ing to obtain money by false pretencesâ€”I saw Bint at Sheffield and in consequence of a conversation with him inquiries were made which resulted in the institution of these proceedings against Bintâ€”I know Bint's writingâ€”the signatures to these receipts for five fares "A. H. Bint "are his; also the calculations in figures on the back of this letter the hours of work in the statements the signatures to the wages sheets this address "Mr. A. Bint 21 Burnley Road Stockwell Road. London" and the receipts for registered letters dated July 18th and August 10th.

Cross-examined. By talking to the directors I knew that the prisoner had had a good characterâ€”I knew he had been employed by the London School Board for six years and a half; by Johnson Brothers architects in Carlisle for twelve months and by Ebners of 150 Old Street St. Luke's four years before he was engaged as inspector and foreman in our firm but I understood from the director who engaged him that he did not make very strict inquiries into his references but took him because he happened to be at that time with the School Board in temporary employment in Clerken
wellâ€”I have the general supervision of the staff including the prisonerâ€”he supervised the outdoor foremenâ€”we have discussed the possibility of outdoor foremen defrauding the companyâ€”he continually suggested piece work because we could have an absolute check he saidâ€”generally I was in favour of time workâ€”Cairo was an outdoor foremanâ€”he was prosecuted and convicted of fraudulently tampering with his time sheets and obtaining moneyâ€”I differed from the prisoner as to whether the Sheffield job was time or piece workâ€”our Mr. Tyrrell settles whether the job is to be a time or piece jobâ€”he would only consult me in very special circumstancesâ€”practically my instructions were to make them all time jobsâ€”when no price is stated on the foreman's instructions the job is done as time work and when it is piece work the price is statedâ€”as it is in the document produced at 1s. 0 1/2d. per square yard the foreman has to bring the work out at that priceâ€”if it cost more he would lose; if less he has the benefitâ€”the clerk hands the document to the foreman and the price is marked on in red inkâ€”in time work the document is the same except that the price is omittedâ€”we have one other travelling foreman who looks after the London jobsâ€”the prisoner supervised jobs in the country of which we gave him a listâ€”he was under no supervisionâ€”all supervision over country jobs was done by the prisonerâ€”in all parts of the United Kingdom Scotland and Ireland the foremen make weekly returns of the wages the men and the hours which the travelling foreman checksâ€”the foremen on the various jobs never know when he is coming to check the work and to see that we get the work for the money we pay outâ€”upon a large job he is very regular in his visits probably once a week according to his discretionâ€”he would have to travel about and go to any job which we indicated to himâ€”he would suggest that it was advisable to go to certain placesâ€”the time his visit would require would be from a day or half a day to a few hoursâ€”he had a wide discretionâ€”we made it a rule for him to be at the office on Fridays when the wages sheets were checked and if a foreman's claim seemed excessive we drew his attention to itâ€”he would only know whether it was correct from his knowledge acquired on a visitâ€”we have about half a dozen foremen including Ettore who speaks English fairly well and reads it better than he speaks it but we have sometimes the services of an interpreterâ€”my conversation with Caccavale was mostly through an interpreterâ€”part of our business is that of flooring the interior of buildings for which we have large contractsâ€”from eighty to 100 men are employedâ€”about 20 per cent are Italiansâ€”on outdoor work we have had as many as 500 men on one contract; all Englishâ€”the Italians may have to employ somebody to make out their sheetsâ€”the prisoner
has never stated that the jobs could not be done at the price put upon the jobs for the foremen.

Re-examined. Placing reliance upon the prisoner we sent him to visit jobs which he suggestedâ€”he was on no business of the firm in Sheffield and had no right to be thereâ€”I caused a subpoena to be served on him and sent for himâ€”I said "You know what I am here for?"â€”he replied "Yes there is some dirty trickery going on behind my back; why are these matters not left to me?"â€”I said "Since when have the company relegated these matters to you?"â€”he said "Never mind it is my busi
ness"â€”I asked him to go into the witness box and he said if he did he would say that the work was piece workâ€”that was Cairo's defenceâ€”the prisoner did not give evidenceâ€”Cairo was convicted by the Jury before the Assistant Recorder.

ARTHUR HILLS TYRRELL . I live at 175 Cassland Road South Hackneyâ€”I have been employed by the Acme Wood Flooring Company fourteen yearsâ€”I am now chief clerk in the flooring department and have the superintendence of flooring contractsâ€”the prisoner's duty was to report in writing the result of his investigations into the various jobs to me including the number of men employed and the hours worked and so onâ€”one job was at Skewen near Neath, South Wales the foreman appointed as appears in my writing in this document being Marstonâ€”the name Ettore is written over the name Marston in consequence of the prisoner stating on May 29th that he would do the job betterâ€”I had confidence in Bint at that timeâ€”he said five men would be necessaryâ€”I know Bint inspected the job because I had his written report which did not mention the number of men but I believed Bint.
Cross-examined. I do not know that Marston's work was unsatisfactoryâ€”I know nothing against him.

GEORGE STOWERS . I am a director of the Acme Wood Flooring Companyâ€”this receipt for five fares to Neath of May 29th is Bint's writingâ€”the names of Ettore and Caccavale at the foot of it have been addedâ€”I gave Bint Â£5 in exchange for that receiptâ€”I had every confidence in him.

Cross-examined. We had good characters of the prisoner when we engaged himâ€”the Â£3 was an approximate amount for the fares which would have to be accounted forâ€”I saw the prisoner's reports.â€”he was in our service many years.
Re-examined. Marston has been in our employment twelve years and is still a good workman.

HENRY WILLIAM JEFFERY . I am secretary of the Acme Wood Flooring Companyâ€”I received this receipt from Mr. Stowers and gave him the Â£5 it refers toâ€”this document referring to the fares to Skewen Â£4 5s. is my writingâ€”Ettore and Caccavale went thereâ€”the receipt for fares to Ystalyfera is in Bint's writingâ€”I got the figures from Bint on May 29thâ€”between May 29th and June 3th he told me he had given Ettore Â£4 5s. for five faresâ€”Â£2 11s. was paid to Caccavaleâ€”I made this note under Bint's instructionsâ€”the amount is Â£6 16s.â€”the Â£7 17s. 9 1/2d. is the amount of the wages sheet from Skewen for the weekâ€”the wages sheet shows five men were employed including one named Francisco Dinverno

who appears upon the sheet to have been paid Â£1 3s. 3d.â€”believing that to be a genuine document I sent bank notes and postal orders for Â£7 17s. 9 1/2d. for the wages and fares to Ettore the foreman at Skewenâ€”the wages sheet for June 11th shows Â£15 8s. 11d. and that Dinverno was still working and earning Â£2 18s. 6d.â€”on June 17th the amount was Â£15 7s. 9d. when Dinverno was still working and is entered as earning Â£2 18s. 6d.â€”the fares are made up as 16s. 10d. to Neath from Paddington and 1s. 4d. to Skewenâ€”I sent those moneysâ€”the wages sheet on June 25th is Â£19 19s. 3d.â€”Dinverno is still stated to be workingâ€”the wages sheet for June 11th from Ystalyfera is Â£10 11s. 10d.â€”it shows three men and ninety-two hours for that week and refers to Â£2 Us. paid for three fares to Ystalyfera with reference to that jobâ€”it is signed "A. H. Bint"â€”the amount was paid to Bint when he was at the officeâ€”when Bint was going to a job he would take the money with himâ€”three fares are also paid back to London and a pay sheet followed the day of coming homeâ€”this is a wages sheet for the Plymouth job of July 15th signed by Ettore and purporting to show Â£13 15s. 9d. due for wages from the company in respect of fourteen hours a day except Saturday when they are nineâ€”believing the statement to be true on July 17th I sent the bank notes and postal orders for the amountâ€”the Â£15 5s. 6d. for July 29th in accord
ance with the sheet signed "A. H. Bint "I paid to Bint at the officeâ€”the Â£19 0s. 10d. for five men at fourteen hours a day I sent the next day to Bint as appears from the letter book by post on August 6thâ€”Â£12 was also sent on account of Â£12 13s. 10d. in two Â£5 notes and a postal order as appears from the endorsement and the receipt dated July 17th.

Cross-examined. The amounts include fares and other expensesâ€”between May 29th and June 5th Bint said he had paid five fares to Ettore in London or on the works probably in Londonâ€”"We note you mention five fares "is my communication to Bint as well as the request to book it on the next week's sheet and deduct the Â£4 5s. advancedâ€”it was booked on 17th in Ettore's writing that he had received itâ€”I paid out these moneysâ€”twenty or thirty pay sheets would come in each week according to the businessâ€”I have asked Bint to examine the sheetsâ€”I cannot say how many; he was rarely at the officeâ€”on one or two occasions I have landed him the money but when he was travelling about the country I have sent it by post.

JOSEPH DUFFY . I am the general manager of the Acme Wood Flooring Company Limitedâ€”on Bennett's return from Cairo's prosecution at Sheffield he made some statements to meâ€”I have no doubt that was a time job.

Cross-examined. We did the work on the basis of the superficial areaâ€”I do not remember Bint ever reporting that it could not be done at the priceâ€”the prisoner has recommended piece work verbally but I do not recollect his having done so in writing.
Re-examined. The work was principally day workâ€”we contracted or the job and paid our men by the hour.
ARCHIBALD ALBERT BAILEY COLEMAN CROSS . I am overseer of the South-Western District Post Office at Stockwell in which district the

prisoner residesâ€”when registered letters are delivered a receipt is taken from someone in the house to whom it is deliveredâ€”these receipts are kept by the post officeâ€”these receipts of June 13th and 20th for registered letters delivered at 21 Burnley Road Stockwell from Neath and the receipts of July 18th 25th and August 10th from Plymouth are signed "A. H. Bint "as well as that from Southall on July 18thâ€”the latter is stamped "1.15 p.m."

ISAAC HARRIS . I live at Skewen near Neathâ€”I was clerk of the works on a job of flooring the school rooms that was carried out by the Acme Wood Flooring Company for the Skewen School Board in Juneâ€”four men were engaged on the workâ€”the job lasted about a monthâ€”I saw Bint there two or three timesâ€”he told me he was the manager of the Acme Companyâ€”the schools were intended to accommodate 450 children.
Cross-examined. There were night class rooms and a big hall.

AMATA ETTORE (Partly interpreted.) I have been working for the Acme Wood Flooring Companyâ€”I was made a foreman about a year ago by the companyâ€”the beginning of this year Bint appointed me foreman on a job at Southall in May I thinkâ€”he said "I got this job for you; you must give me 1/2d. a yard on the job"â€”afterwards he asked for moreâ€”I was working piece workâ€”later on he asked me to put more men on the time sheetâ€”he asked me for money and said "Put more hours on the time sheet"â€”he wrote a little note to show me how to do itâ€”I put one hour for each man per dayâ€”I gave him moneyâ€”he said "I have got a big job for you down at Plymouth"â€”that was when I had finished the job at Southallâ€”he said he had another job for me at Skewenâ€”that was the Saturday before the Whitsun Bank Holiday June lst I thinkâ€”in Caccavale's house he gave me a paper and said he had fares for five menâ€”he gave me Â£3 8s. for four men and said "I will keep this fare for me and you and for the extra man you will send me so much a week"â€”I was to put an extra name on the time sheet to make the five menâ€”I started to Neath on a Tuesday with three other men about June 2nd and did four hours' workâ€”we worked on Wednesday and Thursday and I sent up a wages sheetâ€”the fifth man I called Francisco Dinvernoâ€”he was never thereâ€”on the Thursday he was put down as earning Â£1 3s. 3d. on this time sheetâ€”this is my receipt "Received from Bint five fares"â€”I did not put the amount because I did not know how much Bint had receivedâ€”on June 6th I received this letter from the company enclosing the amount charged Â£7 17s. 9d. including Â£4 5s. for faresâ€”I had only received Â£3 8s. for faresâ€”before I sent up the next ages sheet Bint came on Wednesday June 10th I thinkâ€”I showed him this letter (From the company asking for the amount of fares) and he wrote a little note on the backâ€”I said I did not know how much to put on the time sheetâ€”he wrote "Five fares to Neath from Farringdon Street 16s. 10d. and 1s. 4d. train from Neath to Skewen"â€”I think I sent that in the next wages sheet for June Nth the sheet I sent having been for June 11thâ€”I charged for the dead man Dinverno for the week Â£2 18s. 6d.â€”I sent Â£1 10s. a week to the prisoner by registered letter or gave it to

himâ€”I tore up the receipts after the last job at Risca near Newport in consequence of a letter I received from Bint nine or ten weeks agoâ€”I continued to put Dinverno on the time sheet of June 17th as having received Â£2 18s. 6d.â€”I received Â£15 7s. 9d. on Saturday 20thâ€”he never worked at allâ€”I sent the prisoner two or three registered letters from Skewen containing 90s.â€”on June 25th I sent another pay sheet to the company in which Dinverno's name appeared as having earned Â£2 18s. 6d. and this application for the fares back to London for five menâ€”I came to London with the men on the Saturdayâ€”I received Â£19 19s. 3d.â€”on the Sunday I went and handed Bint Â£2 10s. for the fares and his "wages"â€”altogether I paid him over Â£10 for four weeksâ€”Caccavale first worked at Ystalyferaâ€”Bint went with us there about June 10thâ€”Allocca was employed there with Caccavaleâ€”Bint was with me in a public house from about four o'clock till twelve o'clock at nightâ€”he got the fares to Swansea and spent Â£2 10s. and I went to see him again at eight in the morning when he had gone to Plymouthâ€”he told me the next job was At Plymouthâ€”on that occasion I gave him moneyâ€”I went to two little jobs first and then I went to Plymouthâ€”Bint appointed meâ€”I sent in this wages sheet of July 15th in which five men are stated to have worked fourteen hours when four men worked eight hours and a halfâ€”the men usually work twelve hours or twelve hours and a halfâ€”I received Â£18 15s. 9d. on July 18th from the company and sent Â£1 10s. to Bint by registered letterâ€”sometimes I received the money by registered letter And sometimes by telegramâ€”I did the same with the wages sheet of July 23rdâ€”the men worked twelve hours and twelve hours and a halfâ€”on every occasion I put wrong hours and men at Bint's suggestionâ€”I sent him 30s. by registered letter on July 24thâ€”these are the receiptsâ€”he came down to the work and told me to put another man on the wages sheet of July 29th and I put Francisco Dinverno as earning Â£2 2s. and the men as working fourteen hours when they worked twelve hours and a halfâ€”he brought Â£14 for the wages and I gave him 10s. moreâ€”I received this letter I think a week after I was at Plymouth from the company's offices in London: "Sirâ€”Please understand that not more than ten hours or ten hours and a half per day must be paid to each man unless I give you instructions.â€”Yours truly A. H. BINT. To Amata Ettore"â€”I think it was the first week in Julyâ€”the men were paid for twelve hours or twelve hours and a halfâ€”in the sheet of August 6th the men are put down as working eighteen hours and Dinverno is charged for when he was not thereâ€”I received the wages charged and sent 30s. to Bintâ€”we finished at Plymouth after that sheetâ€”Bint appointed me as foreman at the school job at Risca on October 5th 1903.

Cross-examined. I have worked for the Acme* Company about two years nine months as foreman and about one year before thatâ€”I was a foreman when Bint cameâ€”I never falsified the sheets before the Southall job nor the sheets of any other employerâ€”I was never charged with doing itâ€”I was employed by Geary and Walkerâ€”they owed me money when I left their employmentâ€”they paid meâ€”they did not refuse to pay me because I had falsified the time sheetsâ€”I did not tell Bint that I

had been treated badly by Geary and Walkerâ€”when I came back from Glasgow they paid me as soon as it was dueâ€”their work was piece workâ€”they never accused me of falsifying the accountsâ€”I never borrowed money from Bintâ€”he never advanced me moneyâ€”I received Â£2 from him on the Southall job because my money had gone to the wrong place that the company owed me and I left him a note on the Monday morningâ€”I repaid him at the company's officesâ€”I left it with the cashierâ€”I have never borrowed money from Bintâ€”when I went to Skewen I had money of my own to carry me on for the weekâ€”my fellow workmen had enough money and if I had not enough the company would give it to meâ€”I did not say to Bint when I went to Skewen "I have no money to go with; would you lend me 30s.? I will send it to you back when I get my money"â€”I sent Bint Â£1 10s. and not 10s. on June 13thâ€”I did not send the remaining 10s. on June 20thâ€”when Bint came to Skewen on June 10th the men were not at dinnerâ€”they were working and I followed Bintâ€”the time was 11 or 11.30â€”the men had dinner at one o'clock Bint would see the menâ€”sometimes he would ask for themâ€”I do not remember his asking "Where is the other man?"â€”I did not say "He has gone home to dinner"â€”Bint was there perhaps half an hour and then he went to Ystalyferaâ€”he measured up the workâ€”he did not write on a piece of paper what the cost of the work should beâ€”I do not remember his saying that we must keep within the price of 1s. 4d. a yardâ€”I did not reply that I had to shoot all the blocksâ€”that was not the reason I gave for not keeping to the price of 1s. 4d. a yardâ€”Bint came and said that the company had complained about the work being too expensiveâ€”I said I could not do it otherwise as there was so much to do and I had to shoot the blocks but he knew everything and he was to settle every
thing and he wrote the noteâ€”everything I said to the company Mr. Bint told me to sayâ€”I remember buying a gold watchâ€”at his house Bint asked me the time and when I showed him the watch he wanted me to give it to himâ€”I. told him if he wanted it he would have to pay me Â£12 for itâ€”I did not tell him I had got it cheap or what I had paid for itâ€”I had paid Â£5 in Plymouth for itâ€”I showed it to Mr. and Mrs. Bint when I came back from Plymouth at the end of the jobâ€”I paid for it all at once at Plymouth before I came back to Londonâ€”I did not tell Mr. and Mrs. Bint that I had not been able to pay for the whole of it nor want to borrowâ€”I did not borrow 35s. or pay that money back by instal
ments in registered lettersâ€”Mrs. Bint never gave me any money nor Mr. Bintâ€”I made out my time sheetsâ€”sometimes Bint gave me some notesâ€”I am not good at figuresâ€”I read English very littleâ€”Bint assisted me with figures not at my requestâ€”he told me the totalâ€”when Bint was not there I wrote as I had always written to the companyâ€”I made the calculation of the time sheetsâ€”he showed me how I had to make it outâ€”I told Bint I did not know how much he had got from the company for fares not that I had forgotten how much the fares wereâ€”everybody knew that Bint had those falsifications of time sheets made by everybodyâ€”Paolo Petrilli Beniamino Guiseppe and all my fellow workmen know itâ€”Guiseppe only worked with me two or three weeks and he did

not know itâ€”they did not share in the money; they had only what they got for their workâ€”they never asked for a share in the proceeds of the fraudsâ€”except what I paid to Bint I kept the differenceâ€”I kept the money for the small jobs; I got nothing out of thoseâ€”if I had not done as Bint told me he would not have given me any workâ€”we made an arrangement and I had more workâ€”I received a halfpenny more an hour as foremanâ€”I had been a foreman two months before Bint cameâ€”Mr. Tyrrell preceded Mr. Bint and Mr. Widdicombe who is deadâ€”Tyrrell gave me the work before Bint cameâ€”Widdicombe was the foreman before Bintâ€”I was compelled to work thirteen to fourteen hours and on Saturday eight nine or tenâ€”I used to put the hours according to the instructions received from Bintâ€”I put what he told meâ€”I was paid for more hours than I did even on the longest dayâ€”I used to go to work before the other workmenâ€”I only charged thirteen hoursâ€”I took the extra hour out of the overcharge for other workmenâ€”there were three men and myselfâ€”I was overpaid four hours and I got Â£2 18s. 6d. entered for Dinvernoâ€”Bint told me to put another name and I put that nameâ€”I invented the nameâ€”I charged the extra hours and the faresâ€”Bint took the fares back to London at his houseâ€”I went there and took him Â£2 10s.â€”the sheet shows Â£3 19s. Id.â€”I paid Bint so much a week then I had to pay him for the small workâ€”I mean jobs of from thirty to seventy yards in London and in the countryâ€”Bint gave them to me as piece work but I had no order to that effect from the companyâ€”I used to do it piece work and sign on the sheet by the hourâ€”Bint took from 5s. to Â£1 out of itâ€”I paid him Â£1 5s. a week on a job at Frinton on another job at Minster near Ramsgate and another at Wingham near Dover; also on jobs at Chichester Newbury Windsor Castle New Cross and "The Grapes "St. Mary Axeâ€”that is all I rememberâ€”Bint examined some of those jobs but not allâ€”he came to the job at New Cross and at the American Bank in Londonâ€”I was at Risca near Newportâ€”Bint superintended that jobâ€”I used to send time sheets at first and then I sent a balance sheetâ€”I sent time sheets I think twiceâ€”it was a piece work jobâ€”those time sheets were falsifiedâ€”I sent in time sheets because Bint had given me no instructionsâ€”I had this document before I went on the work but Bint had not told me how I had to do itâ€”at first he told me to put only on the time sheet the money I wanted and the second time he sent a man from London to show me how to make out a balance sheetâ€”at Risca Bint sent a man with a letter to tell me I was to do according to his instructions because there was a man watching meâ€”I did not know I was being watched till Bint sent me that letterâ€”at Risca Bint and Stowers gave me work by pieceâ€”the proprietor sent me two telegrams to do the work by timeâ€”this is the Â£5 watch (Produced).

Re-examined. Geary and Walker never made any accusation against meâ€”when I left they owed me moneyâ€”they paid me and could not give me any more workâ€”they simply asked me to sign a receipt in full settle
mentâ€”this is the receipt (Produced) for the Â£2 I borrowed from Bintâ€”I know his writingâ€”this is his letter (Produced) asking the firm to deduct the Â£2 and this is my telegram to the office for the moneyâ€”I afterwards

went to the office and received Â£4 4s. being Â£2 less than the wages on the sheet Â£6 4s.â€”the receipt is "May 4th 1903. Received Â£4 balance of wages" etc. and that is signed "A. Ettore"â€”Tyrrell appointed me first and then Bintâ€”these (Produced) are some of the returns for the little jobsâ€”we could not falsify them because the price was too smallâ€”I marked exactly the price and the hours because the company would notice if there was any differenceâ€”on the Risca job I falsified the sheetsâ€”I sent Â£1 to Bint of the difference the first weekâ€”after that I did not send more till he sent me instructions; then Bint's letter came to say I was being watched and that I must make the job out to be piece work as the job in fact wasâ€”the letter was written to "Mr. Blank"â€”if I could see the man who brought the letter I could recognise himâ€”he came on a Sunday morningâ€”I sent my papers in on the Thursdayâ€”this is the last sheet I sent in dated October 22ndâ€”the warning about being watched was before thatâ€”I bought the watch I think in High Street Plymouthâ€”Paolo was with me.
AMATA PAOLO (Interpreted.) I was working at Plymouth on the same job as Ettoreâ€”I was with him when he bought the gold watchâ€”I saw him pay for it.

Cross-examined. He paid Â£4 17s. for itâ€”I do not remember how long we had been in Plymouth but we were there four weeksâ€”I think it was about the third weekâ€”the price asked was Â£5â€”I saw Â£4 17s. handed to the shopkeeper.

GIRO CACCAVALE (Interpreted.) I have been employed by the Acme Flooring Company for six yearsâ€”on the way from Broad Street to the office and at my house I asked how the work was going onâ€”he said the work was finished but he said "If you are going to do what I want I will give you work and you will be foreman"â€”I had not been a foreman before thatâ€”we went to the office together and he gave me first some work at Red Hillâ€”he gave me instructions on a piece of paper so that I could copy it on the Saturdayâ€”he wanted me to alter the time to put eleven hours for ten hoursâ€”I was without work and I could not do other
wise but accept what he proposedâ€”I was sent down to be foreman at some works at Ystalyferaâ€”afterwards Bint came to see meâ€”I sent one time sheet before he cameâ€”I copied the number of hours from a piece of paper he gave me when he gave me the work at my house in Londonâ€”I took his note to Ystalyfera and on the Thursday filled in the wages sheet from itâ€”I tore up the paperâ€”the first day the men worked ten hours and on Bint's instructions I put down thirteen and the travellingâ€”I put down thirteen hours on another two days and then fourteen hours or each dayâ€”on June 10th Bint came with Ettore and Allocca and we went to a public house with the clerk of the worksâ€”I paid for drink all round and gave half a sovereign to Bintâ€”the clerk of the works could not see; he was far away from usâ€”the next pay sheet is June 11thâ€”I filled that up from a paper Bint gave me as sixteen hours; the men worked thirteenâ€”I brought that up to the office where I saw Bint and Alloccaâ€”the night we came from the country Bint told me how to make out these sheetsâ€”this one I filled in Londonâ€”Bint told me how many hours; I

could not do it otherwiseâ€”he told me I had done the work too cheapâ€”he asked me to alter the hours from thirteen which I had putâ€”Bint asked me for the sheet and he went into the office and took itâ€”he came out of the office to me with the sheet and said I was a fool; then I said "Take the sheet and make it yourself better"â€”he could not alter that sheet he had to give it to the officeâ€”he took it back thereâ€”he brought out the money took Â£1 2s. for himself and gave me the differenceâ€”he said "That is for me and that is for you"â€”I afterwards went as foreman of some works at Southallâ€”I sent in a wages sheet on July 16thâ€”I made it out at Bint's house the week beforeâ€”he came to me and said "You come at four o'clock to my house and I will make out the sheet"â€”Ciccone worked four days I put him down sixâ€”Bint told me to do thatâ€”he made out a bill that I was to send him 30s.â€”the five men were Caccavale Leonardo Sparnpanalo Ciccone and Ciniglioâ€”I put one hour less for the other menâ€”they worked eleven hoursâ€”Bint gave me this paper "Mr. A.
