Bint Burnley Road Stockwell Road London S.W."â€”there was only Â£1 left after I paid all the men and I sent a boy to register a letter to his house with the moneyâ€”the boy wrote the envelope in which I put Â£1 and not 30s.â€”I sent it to the address given at 9.30 a.m. on July 18thâ€”I do not remember Cairo's trial at Sheffield but Bint told me he had six weeksâ€”he came to me on Sunday October 25th or 26thâ€”he came to my houseâ€”I was not in but I met him and we went into a public houseâ€”he said "Cairo has got six weeks; you come to the office to-morrow" and if Mr. Duffy asked whether I have given any money to him I was to say "No."

Cross-examined. I said before the Magistrate that Bint's son had come to me for moneyâ€”that is trueâ€”the elder son came once and another time a thin oneâ€”once on a Saturday once on a Thursday night and twice on a Sunday this boy and his brother came; four timesâ€”(A boy was brought forward.)â€”it was this one twice and another one onceâ€”once he came to me because his father wanted meâ€”he came to bring me back a poundâ€”(The interpreter complained that this witness spoke a patois and not Italian and said that he could not understand all his dialect.)â€”I came from Naplesâ€”I worked in Russell Square in May or June lastâ€”I never borrowed 2s. from the prisonerâ€”he never lent me any money.

Re-examined. The prisoner's boy came to my house for money twiceâ€”he said that his father had sent him for money; he did not say how much and I gave him 10s. to give to his fatherâ€”before we went to Southall the boy had come and got 5s.â€”he came after we came back from Southallâ€”he said "My father has told me that you should send money"â€”he did not say what sumâ€”it was after I had sent him 20s. from Southallâ€”the boy told me his father wanted to see meâ€”I could not go and I gave him 2s. for trains and told him to go back.

AMATA ETTORE (Re-examined by MR. MUIR). On the Saturday or Sunday before going to Plymouth Bint left me a note that I should go and see himâ€”I wentâ€”I did not ask him to lend me some money as I had a chance to buy a gold watchâ€”he did not lend me 35s.â€”I did not tell him I wanted that money towards the priceâ€”when I went there Mrs. Bint was down stairsâ€”I do not know if she was cooking the dinnerâ€”she and her

husband were with me in the up stairs sitting room but not on that dayâ€”she did not hand her husband Â£1 10s. in gold and 5s. in silverâ€”he did not hand that sum to me nor say "You want this to buy a watch"â€”I did not say. "I will send it you from the country; I cannot give it you all at once but I will give it to you as I can"â€”I showed this gold watch to Mrs. Bint when I came back from Plymouthâ€”she did not say "You seem to be making. a lot of money"â€”I did not say "I have no money at all; everything is very expensive at Plymouth"â€”I did not say anything of that kind to her.

Re-examined. I went to Bint's house because of a letter he sent meâ€”he left a little note at the office "Let Mr. Ettore come to me in the morning" and when I saw him he asked me for one fareâ€”I never got it from himâ€”I took four men; Bint asked me to take threeâ€”I said "You must not think you are going to do as you did the last time when you made the office pay for five tickets instead of four; this time you won't do it" and I refused to pay him the fareâ€”I do not remember the day I went to Plymouthâ€”it was about Monday June 29thâ€”I had been there three years before for the same companyâ€”Paolo my cousin saw this watch in a shop window and told me about it and I bought itâ€”I was working with it.

AMATA PAOLO (Re-examined.) I saw this watch first and wanted to buy it for myselfâ€”it was in a window and there was a ticket on it with the priceâ€”at the end of the week I told Ettore I should like to buy it if he was going to lend me some moneyâ€”I asked him to go to the shopâ€”I had never been at Plymouth before I went there on this job.

Cross-examined. I had a silver watch but I thought I should like to have that watchâ€”Ettore had already a gold oneâ€”we went into the shop and Ettore asked if the shopkeeper would make any reductionâ€”he wanted 5s. oft the Â£5â€”he said he wanted it and as I had not the money he bought it because it was cheap.
Re-examined. I went to Skewen with Ettoreâ€”there were four men altogetherâ€”Dinverno was never working on the jobâ€”when Bint came to the job at the school the men were working.

By MR. MUIR. I did not know Ettore was falsifying the sheetsâ€”he told me he had given money to Bint otherwise I should not knowâ€”that is how I came to knowâ€”I knew it two or three months before these proceedingsâ€”I knew it at Skewen.

FRANCISCO ALLOCCA (Partly interpreted.) I was working with Caccavale in June at Ystalyfera and remember Bint coming one Wednesdayâ€”after some time Caccavale the clerk of the works Bint me and another chap went to a public houseâ€”after we had been drinking some time Bint said he had to go away to catch a train; then I saw Caccaval put ore hand behind his back and give Bint a sovereign or half sovereign I could not see which but I saw goldâ€”when we came back to the office in London Bint was with Caccavale about twenty minutesâ€”we waited for Bintâ€”when he came he asked Caccavale for his time sheetâ€”Cacca
vale said "I have given it in at the office"â€”Bint said "Oh you fool why didn't you put more hours because you have done the job too quick?"

â€”Caccavale said "Very well I will put twenty-four hours a day; if you want to put more make it out yourself"â€”then Bint said "Put twenty-four hours a day"â€”Bint took the sheet back into the office to get the moneyâ€”he brought it out in his hand and said to Caccavale "This is yours and this is mine"â€”he had money in both handsâ€”he put his money in his pocket and I and the other men divided the other money between us.

Cross-examined. I saw Bint give Caccavale 22s. and Â£1â€”I found out about putting wrong figures on the Friday two weeks after we went to Ystalyferaâ€”it was in London when Bint told me to explain to Caccavale why he had not put more hours because Caccavale could not understand anything about figuresâ€”Bint and Caccavale told me that more hours were being put than were workedâ€”that was when we finished at Ystalyferaâ€”that was when I saw money pass between Bint and Caccavaleâ€”Caccavale told me he had to pay Bint half a sovereignâ€”on the way to the station Bint told Ettore to go and take the tickets and after this the train came and they went awayâ€”Caccavale said "Did you see that I had to pay Bint 10s.?"â€”I asked him why he gave him that moneyâ€”he said that if he did not give him the money he would not give us any more workâ€”the time sheet was still to be made outâ€”Caccavale said we were to show more work than we did and give more hours otherwise Bint would not give us any more work.

WILLIAM SMITH (Detective J.) On November 2nd I found Bint de
tainedâ€”I read the warrant to himâ€”it charged him that he did unlawfully by means of false pretences obtain Â£5 and other sums from the Acme Wood Flooring Company with intent to defraudâ€”he said "They owe. me that amount now and Mr. William Duffy owes me Â£42 and I have left in hand as much as Â£20 or Â£30 travelling expenses."

The prisoner in his defence on oath said that only with regard to appointing a small proportion of foremen did the firm ask his advice; that it was im
possible for anybody to check the foremen's returns of the hours and the number of men employed on the various jobs considering the number of them he had to visit; that he simply had the time sheets put in front of him and if he saw anything doubtful he inquired into the matter but he never suggested the falsification of time sheets to anyone and never made any fraudulent returns nor any arrangement with the foremen for the falsification of time sheets; that he gave Ettore five fares and believed that the men stated 'were sent and were at work in every case but on arriving at Skewen in the dinner hour and on all occasions having to inspect other jobs he could not remain on the works and if anything was wrong he was himself deceived but he did his best to satisfy himself as to general results and never had any intention to defraud his employers; that the statement about his handing Caccavale gold in the public house was absolutely false; that he lent Ettore 35s. to help him to buy a gold watch and lent other sums to the foremen which they repaid in instalments some of which were shown by the receipts for the registered letters produced.; and that he had sent in only truthful reports and had never had any charges made against him before.

JUELETTA BINT I am the prisoner's wifeâ€”we have been married twenty-three yearsâ€”I live with him at Stockwellâ€”I know that he has been in the habit of advancing money to workmenâ€”Ettore has been at our house on several occasionsâ€”he has borrowed moneyâ€”on Sunday June 28th it being two days before my birthday Ettore came and I had words with my husband about these Italians coming as they are a dis
reputable lot of people but Ettore was asked into the residing room and my husband went to him and as I went on cooking the dinner they had a conversation togetherâ€”I was in the kitchen when my husband came to me and asked if I would lend Ettore 35s.â€”I said "Oh dear I do not know; that is a lot of money more than you have been used to lending; I do not think I would do you?"â€”he said "It will be all right; he wants to buy an expensive watch"â€”I said "Well I do not know; I have worked very hard for that money and I do not like the idea"â€”ultimately I lent itâ€”I went from the kitchen to the bedroom opened a box and took out the money which I took and handed to my husband in the sitting roomâ€”to the best of my recollection it was 35s. paid by a sovereign a half sovereign and some silverâ€”no receipt was givenâ€”Ettore never gave a receipt for what he borrowed of my husbandâ€”he said he wanted to buy a valuable watch from a friend and that he would pay the money back by instalmentsâ€”I afterwards saw the watch in Ettore's possessionâ€”I am not good at dates but it was before or after the Plymouth journey that my husband called my attention to this man's gold watch and I said "It is a splendid watch; I should be afraid to carry it"â€”Ettore offered to sell it to my husband for Â£12 but I said "I should be afraid to carry such a thing"â€”I said "You must have been making a lot of money in Plymouth"â€”he said "No things are expensive in Plymouth and I have not been able to save much money"â€”later I had a registered letter with half a sovereign in itâ€”I put the letter in the fireâ€”I had letters after thatâ€”I had three instalments of half sovereignsâ€”it was my money and I put it in my boxâ€”I do not know whether my husband saw it or notâ€”I remember a registered letter coming from Caccavale; it contained postage stampsâ€”I never knew my boy or any boy going to Caccavale for money or bringing back money.

Cross-examined. I understood that Ettore was a good workman but that he had not sufficient money to buy a watchâ€”the money was sent back to A. H. Bint not to meâ€”I did not pass that money to Ettore but to my husbandâ€”the instalment was sent with a dirty scrawl of "10s. on account" on a single piece of paper with no name and I had to infer from the postal address where it came from and who sent itâ€”I never knew Caccavale send 10s.; he sent stampsâ€”I never saw a letter from Caccavaleâ€”he has been at our house repeatedlyâ€”I looked upon these Italians constantly coming as a nuisance sometimes three or four times a week and I have had more trouble with my husband about that than about anything during our married life but he said "They are good workmen and I must make a name with the firm"â€”I cannot say

how often Cairo came but I have seen himâ€”I kept the money which was sent because it belonged to me as I had lent it to my husband who gave me a weekly allowanceâ€”I have never had money from Cairoâ€”I have sent money by post and I have lent money on several occasions and he has sent to my house not by registered letter but by letter and by handâ€”I lent him money because he told me his wife was starving.
ARTHUR BINT . The prisoner is my fatherâ€”I am fifteen years of ageâ€”I know Caccavaleâ€”I have never carried money from him to my father or been asked to.

Cross-examined. I have been twice to Caccavale's houseâ€”I have had a watchâ€”my father gave it to meâ€”I have not had one from the Italiansâ€”I got it from my father when I was at the Honeywell Road School for going up a standardâ€”I know Ettoreâ€”when he came to our house he gave me a broken watch and said it would be a good watch if I would pay 2s. 6d. and get it mendedâ€”I had forgotten that when I said I had had no watch from the Italiansâ€”I knew Ettore was an Italianâ€”Caccavale has been to our place; I cannot tell you whenâ€”the first time was in the summerâ€”it is a long time since; I cannot rememberâ€”I go to workâ€”I was at work in the summerâ€”I leave off at 6 o'clock and 1.30 on Satur
daysâ€”I cannot say it was Saturday July 18th but my father gave me a messageâ€”the Italian did not give me any moneyâ€”father said "Go to Caccavale and tell him some polishing has got to be done "so I went to his houseâ€”I did not know he was at work at Southallâ€”I did not take another message that father wanted 30s. nor that if he did not pay it he would get no more work nor any more jobsâ€”the message seemed sensible and Caccavale seemed to understand it because it was put in a sensible way but that is all that I can rememberâ€”I have not been talking about this caseâ€”my father asked me what I could say about these two visitsâ€”I have told the truthâ€”the second visit father sent me to Caccavale and said he wanted to see himâ€”I said in broken sentences that something was the matter with the workâ€”he came down stairs then went back again and then came back with meâ€”nothing was said about 5s.â€”he did not pay my tram fare father always did thatâ€”Caccavale never gave me 2s. nor any money nor any of themâ€”I did not know what I had to say till I came hereâ€”nobody told me; I never mentioned it to mother nor father nor to the solicitor nor to anybody till I got in the box.

Re-examined. I have been at this Court three days; I did not come yesterday (Friday)â€”my mother told me that the Italians said I brought money from them to my fatherâ€”she did not ask whether it was true but I told her it was not true.

p.hi: The prisoner received a good character.

div1.p:
GUILTY .
Eighteen months' hard labour.

102.
ELLEN LOUISA FORD
PLEADED GUILTY to
stealing a piece of lace the property of
Edith Ford;
also a diamond ring the property of
William King;
also two skirts the property of
Elizabeth King.
Judg
ment respited in order to see if she could be sent abroad. â€”And

(103).
THOMAS CHARLES HONNOR (37)
to unlawfully converting to his own use cer
tain money entrusted to him by
Richard Joseph Blake . (A previous conviction was proved against him).
Judgment respited.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

104.
WILLIAM JOHN HICKS (28)
LAURA HICKS (23) and
SELINA BAKER (25)
Feloniously making eight counterfeit shillings. WILLIAM JOHN HICKS
PLEADED GUILTY . No evidence was offered against BAKER.
NOT GUILTY .

BRIDGET LATHAM . I am an assistant to my mother at a tobacconist's shop 6 Rathbone Street Canning Townâ€”I served the prisoner Laura Hicks with 1d. worth of shag on November 8thâ€”she tendered a shillingâ€”I tested it and it bentâ€”I handed it back to her and she ran away with itâ€”she came again on Sunday 29th in the evening for 1d. worth of shagâ€”she tendered this shillingâ€”I took it to my mother who came and told the prisoner it was bad and sent me for a constableâ€”I saw mother test it; it bent and she handed the coin to a constable.
Cross-examined by Laura Hicks. I am sure you are the same woman who came three weeks before November 29th and that evening.

FREDERICK TEGG (117 K.) About 7.45 on November 29th I was called to a tobacconist's shop in Rathbone Streetâ€”Latham handed me this shilling and pointing to Laura Hicks said "This woman has handed me this bad shilling: she came into this shop about three weeks ago and handed me one then"â€”I said to Laura "Have you any more coins about you?"â€”she said "No that is the only shilling I had and I did not know it was a bad one or I should not have tried to change it here; I have three children at home"â€”I took her to the stationâ€”on the way she dropped somethingâ€”I picked up a purse which contained seven or eight shillings five dated 1900 and two 1898â€”I said "Where did you get them from?â€”she said "My brother Bill gave them to me; I do not know where he gets them from"â€”she then handed me a calico bag which contained four packets of tobacco a tin of mustard one egg and a box of matchesâ€”I asked her name and addressâ€”she said "Mary Hicks 85 Fife Road."

FRANCIS CRONK (573 K.) On November 29th about 8.45 p.m. I went to 85 Fife Roadâ€”it was an empty houseâ€”I then went to 87 Fife Roadâ€”I saw the man Hicks and another man leaving No. 87â€”I said "Do you know where Bill Hicks lives?"â€”he said "Nest door but one but they are a rough lot"â€”I conversed with Hicks and Bakerâ€”I took Hicks to the station.

ARTHUR FENNER (243 K.) On Sunday evening November 29th about 10.45 I searched 87 Fife Road where the prisoners Laura and William Hicks and Baker live with Hicks' fatherâ€”in the kitchen table drawer I found eleven white metal spoons; one was partly meltedâ€”in the bed-room

occupied by Hicks and Baker I found a quantity of white metal under a grindstone under a lathe benchâ€”some of the white metal was wrapped in paperâ€”a soldering iron was hanging on the wall and under a table in the same room was this cardboard box containing this plaster of Paris and the two batteriesâ€”I took them to the station.

FREDERICK STEVENS (Detective Officer.) About 11 o'clock on November 29th I went with a constable to 87 Fife Roadâ€”I saw Bakerâ€”I searched the placeâ€”in the back bedroom of Laura Hicks I found these two plaster moulds for making shillings this file a quantity of plaster of Paris and in the bolster on the bed this ladle which had been recently used and metal was in itâ€”in a cupboard in the kitchen were this bottle of spirits of salts a piece of rosin an egg cup containing grease six boxes of vaseline, a box of powder and a quantity of red powderâ€”this electric battery was fixed up inside the cupboard the coil being outside and under a bed in the kitchen was this glue potâ€”the prisoners were charged with having material for the making of counterfeit coinsâ€”William Hicks said "That is right"â€”on November 30th another constable handed me 16s. 10 1/2d. which I examinedâ€”I found a shilling with corresponding date and pattern with the mould taken from William Hicks.

FREDERICK ADAMS (Police Sergeant K.) On Sunday November 29th I as at the Canning Street Police Station when Laura Hicks was brought inâ€”she said to me "It is not my fault it is my brother William's fault who resides with me he gave me the money to take out and sent me three or four times before to pass bad money"â€”she was searched and chargedâ€”I afterwards searched William Hicks and found 16s. 6d. and some coppers upon himâ€”I gave it to Stevens who examined it.

ROBERT VERDON . I am an estate agent for the owner of 87 Fife Roadâ€”the prisoner William Hicks took the flat at 87 Fife Road on July 27th at 7s. 6d. a weekâ€”he deposited 3s.â€”he or Selina Baker paid the rent week by weekâ€”Laura Hicks paid it on two occasionsâ€”it was very often paid in coppers.
WILLIAM JOHN WEBSTER . These eight shillings are counterfeitâ€”six are from this mouldâ€”the two moulds produced are from one patternâ€”most of these articles are connected with counterfeit coining.
Laura Hicks' Defence: "I did not know I was doing any harm or I should never have done it; I have three little children.

LAURA HICKSâ€”
GUILTY .

Nine months' hard labour. W. J. HICKS**â€”
Three years' penal servitude.

105.
HENRY POPE (33)
PLEADED GUILTY to
assaulting
Emma Frances Pope and occasioning her actual bodily harm. The prisoner agreed to execute a deed of separation from his wife the prosecutrix and to allow her. 13s. per week for six months in each year.
Judgment respited.

106.
ARTHUR BILLINGHAM (36)
Forging and uttering a request for the deliverery of ten gross of bottles with intent to defraud.

FREDERICK EDGAR SELTH . I am manager to Percy Thornton Hill and Company bottle merchants of Collingwood Street Blackfriarsâ€”on October 22nd about 11 a.m. the prisoner called on me and said he came from Mr. Roberts of Meson. Fry and Company of Southwark Streetâ€”Mr. Roberts is the manager of the essence department at Fry and Company's essence manufacturersâ€”I had been to try and see Mr. Roberts several times but had not met himâ€”the prisoner stayed talking to me for about thirty minutesâ€”I have no difficulty in recognising himâ€”I took him to be one of the warehousemenâ€”he said they might want thirty gross of bottles a week and asked when I could deliver them as they were rather pushed for themâ€”I picked out some samples for the peculiar work and he went away with them with the understanding that if he brought back an order from his firm that evening I would guarantee two gross of bottlesâ€”he returned bringing this delivery order (Produced) which purports to be signed by Mr. Roberts 88 Southwark Street: "Dear Sirâ€”Samples to hand. Please put ten gross in hand at 12s. 6d. and call and see me to-morrow (Friday) at 12 o'clock"â€”the prisoner called a second time between 4 and 5 p.m.â€”I said "Is that the order?"â€”he said "Mr. Roberts has given me this as he is in a hurry but for the future all our orders will be on printed forms"â€”I put the order in hand as it looked like good business for the future which I had been trying to getâ€”I told my head man not to deliver the goods till I returned and I went to keep the appointmentâ€”I returned with Mr. Fry and he saw the goods and said they had never been orderedâ€”I next saw the prisoner again on November 5th at the corner of St. George's Road and Lambeth Roadâ€”I was in one of my vansâ€”I stopped it and directly the prisoner aw me attempt to get out of it he turned and doubled off down Lambeth Road instead of going down St. George's Roadâ€”I overtook him stopped him and took him up to a constableâ€”he gave the name of Baker living somewhere off the Harrow Roadâ€”I said to the constable "I believe this man is wanted for forging an order"â€”he was taken to the station and detainedâ€”he afterwards gave his name Arthur Billingham.

Cross-examined by the prisoner. When you first came you said you wanted two sample bottles for Mr. Robertsâ€”I said "What Roberts?â€”I put the name of "Fry" on the order myselfâ€”when you ran away from me you ran about thirty yardsâ€”I did not say "There is a warrant for your arrest "I said "I believe Messrs. Fry and Company want you"â€”you walked up to a constable with meâ€”I asked you to get into a cab and drive with me to Fry and Company which you would not do because you said you might meet your governor in Queen Victoria Streetâ€”you did not say to me "There is a warrant against me because my wife ran
away from me and I refused to have anything to do with her" and you did not give that at your reason for running away from meâ€”I believe you said that at the station.

DAVID WILLIAM ROBERTS . I am the manager in the coffee essence department of Charles Fry and Company at 81 Southwark Streetâ€”this delivery order purports to be signed by meâ€”I know nothing of it; it is not my signatureâ€”I know nothing about ordering ten gross of bottlesâ€”it looks as if it was all written by the same handâ€”my name is not Charles Roberts and our real number is 81 and not 88â€”no such order was given to Percy Thornton Hillâ€”the prisoner has not been employed by us during the last eighteen yearsâ€”I do not know him.

THOMAS COTTERELL (384 M.) On November 5th the prosecutor called my attention to the prisonerâ€”I arrested himâ€”he gave his name as Arthur Billinghamâ€”he was charged and made no replyâ€”before being charged he said he knew nothing about itâ€”there was some conversation about his wife and he gave some explanation about giving another name.

p.hi: The prisoner in his defence on oath said that he lived in a Rowton House and while he was writing a letter there about a situation an old man came and asked him if he could help him as he did not seem to be getting on well with it; that the man wrote the letter for him and a few days afterwards he asked him to go to Hill's or Hall's in Collingwood Street and ask for two sample bottles for Fry and Company and say he had come from Mr. Roberts; that he took the bottles to Rowton House and gave them to the man who about two hours afterwards gave him a dosed envelope and told him to take it to Hill's; that he believed it contained the order but that he had not written it and never saw it and did not know its contents; that he did not know the old man's name but thought he was a respectable traveller for a firm; that when he heard that there was a warrant for his arrest he thought it was because his wife had thrown herself on the parish and that he had nothing to do with writing the order and that he had told the detective his story and given a description of the man.

div1.p: FREDERICK EDGAR SELTH (Re-examined.) When the prisoner first came he said "Can you give me some sample bottles?"â€”I said "What sort of bottles"â€”he said "Some light weight bottles"â€”I said "Who are you?"â€”he said "I come from Mr. Roberts of Fry and Company"â€”I said "What do you want them for?"â€”he said it was for a New Zealand shipping order which they had just got and said "Can you do it?"â€”I showed him several kinds of bottlesâ€”he said Mr. Roberts had sent him to get the bottles and he had lost the order or mistook the name and that he had been walking about nearly the whole of the morning trying to find our place and had then seen one of our vansâ€”he did not say that he had just come from Rowton House of which Mr. Roberts was an inmate or that he did not know his name at allâ€”I should not have executed the order if I had known the circumstances under which it had been given to him.

Cross-examined. I did not tell a different story each time I was before the Magistrateâ€”the depositions had to be added to because I was ill.â€”CASTLETON (Detective.) On November 19th I saw the pri
soner

at the back of the police court waiting to appear before the Magistrateâ€”I said "You have told us you work for Morrison in Fenchurch Street; I have been there and they know nothing of you; if you can tell me of any respectable person who can speak in your favour I will do everything I can for you and inform the Court; is there anybody?"â€”he said "No"â€”I said "Nobody at all?"â€”he said "No"â€”I said "I am afraid I cannot do much for you"â€”he said "If you believe me I am innocent of this"â€”I said "Of what?"â€”he said "What I am charged with"â€”I said "If you can prove it or tell me anybody I can go to I will willingly get them hero"â€”he said "I will tell you the truth; I was writing a letter in Rowton House I could not get on with it. A man there asked me if he could do it for me. I let him do it. A day or two afterwards he asked me to take a letter to Messrs. Hill. I did so and this is the trouble I get intoâ€”I said "What is his name?"â€”he said "I do not know"â€”I said "Can you describe him to me?"â€”he said "Yes"â€”he gave me the descrip
tion of a man aged between fifty and sixty dressed in a dark jacket suit and black Trilby hatâ€”I said "Very well I will see if I can find this man"â€”I informed the Magistrate and the prisoner was remanded until November 27th to enable me to find the manâ€”I went to Rowton House and made inquiries but could not find him and the porter did not know himâ€”the prisoner was known there by his description and told me he was a quiet man always keeping to himself.
NOT GUILTY .

107.
ARTHUR BILLINGHAM was again indicted
for unlawfully attempting to obtain ten cross of bottles from
Percy Thornton Hill and others by false pretences and with intent to defraud.

p.hi: for the prosecution offered no evidence.

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

108.
SARAH GUE (37)
, For the manslaughter of
Sidney Edward Gue.
LEONARD MEYER . I am not qualified according to law but I am a student of medicineâ€”I have seen Mary Ann Gue: she is in an unfit state to travel having been lately confined.

WILLIAM DAVIS (Detective Sergeant.) I was present at the police court when the depositions of Mary Ann Gue were takenâ€”the prisoner was present and had an opportunity of cross-examining her; they are signed by herâ€”I was also present at the Coroner's inquest when she gave her evidence on oath: she signed her deposition (This is it): "I am the wife of Walter Gue a carman of 24 Wolseley Buildings Dockhead Bermondsey. Mrs. Henry Gue is my sister. She came to me about noon on Tuesday November 10th 1903. She had the deceased child Sidney with her. I went to her house to help her with her work because her breast was bad. I stayed at her house until 5 p.m. o'clock and then wont with her on errands. We got back home again a little before 6 p.m. o'clock. I swear that all the time she was with me she had no drinks; that is ever since noon She

was going for a tin of milk so I took the child from her at the door and took him upstairs. I had looked at the child once or twice while we were cut, but noticed nothing wrong with himâ€”he had cried: the mother put the child to breast two or three times but he did not take it; he had had the bottle (milk) between 1 o'clock and 2 o'clock p.m. When I got the child indoors I noticed him working his arms about: I called the child's sister. Florrie Gue. In about two minutes I found the child was dead. My sister the mother of the deceased came in soon. I told her and she began to cry She had only been away four or live minutes to get the milk. The doctor came in and said the child was dead. The child seemed to me to be quite well when we took him out first. "When my sister came to me at noon she looked as if she had had too much to drink, but she had no more to drink all day while with me. She was carrying the child and seemed to carry it all right. He had a hat on and a shawl over him, but his face was not covered over. My sister was carrying the child all the time herself while we were out of doors. No one else curried the deceased."(Deposition before the Magistrate read:) "I am the sister of the prisoner of 24 Wolseley Buildings. Dockhead. The prisoner and her hus
band live at 14 Fort Buildings. Between 12 and 1 p.m. on Tuesday Novem
ber 10th the prisoner called for me. She had the child with her. The child seemed in good health. It was wrapped in a shawl and had a woollen cap. The prisoner had it in her arms;â€”we went out together. Prisoner carrying the baby and reached home about 1 p.m. I stayed with her (here till nearly 5 p.m. Prisoner was nursing it all that time; she fed it too. The baby seemed all right. At 3 p.m. we went out to do some shopping. We came back about 6 p.m.: prisoner had the child with her all the time. When we got back prisoner handed me the child to take up stairs. She was going out to get a tin of milk.' The child was all right then. I carried it on my arm: the face was not covered. At the top of the stairs the child did a kind of a flutter in my arms; I looked at it; it seemed rather pale and I placed my hand on Its forehead and I found it cold. I thought it was dead. I called Florence (13). and sent her for the doctor. Between 12 and 6 we never entered any public house. Prisoner had no drink while with me and seemed sober."

FLORENCE. GUE . I am the prisoner's daughterâ€”on November 10th 1 was at. home when my aunt came in carrying the deceasedâ€”in conse
quence of what she said I fetched Dr. O'Reilly.

GEORGE HARTLEY O'REILLY M.D. M.R.C.S. Between 3 and 5.30 p.m. on November 10th I was called to Fort Buildings to see a childâ€”I found it lying dead on a sofaâ€”I made a post mortem examination next day and found that it had died from asphyxiaâ€”it was a healthy well nourished childâ€”as far as I could make out there was nothing to cause its deathâ€”I saw the prisoner on the 10th: she seemed very excited and as if she had been drinkingâ€”in my opinion she was not then in a fit state to have charge of a child.

p.hi: said that he did not consider the evidence sufficient and directed the Jury to return a verdict of

div1.p: NOT GUILTY .

109.
RICHARD DERRIMAN (24)
PLEADED GUILTY ** to
unlawfully uttering two counterfeit half sovereigns within ten days.
Six previous convictions were proved against him.
Nine months' hard labour. â€”And

(110).
GEORGE HOBSON (19)
to unlawfully uttering two counterfeit half-sovereigns within ten days.
Five months' hard labour.
[Pleaded guilty: See original trial image.]

111.
JOHN NORTON (27)
BARBARA LUMLEY (27). and
ELLEN BLAKE (36)
Feloniously assaulting
Matthew Mason with intent to rob him of his goods and moneys.

RICHARD DAVIES (373 M.) On the morning of November 11th I was in Little Lant Street. Boroughâ€”I saw the prosecutor with the female prisonersâ€”the male prisoner was about ten yards behindâ€”they went to
wards Lombard Street. S.E.â€”I followed themâ€”I had silent boots onâ€”I saw Norton seize the prosecutor by the throat and the women rifled his pocketsâ€”there was a scuffle on the groundâ€”I rushed for the male prisonerâ€”he ran awayâ€”after chasing him through several by streets. I secured himâ€”the women got awayâ€”I was hurt on the knee by the male prisoner and was on the sick list for many daysâ€”I heard the prosecutor call out during the struggle "Police! Murder"â€”I heard Norton say "Have you got his b----money?"â€”that was to one of the women. I could not say whichâ€”I never lost sight of Norton whilst I was chasing him.

Cross-examined by Norton. I was within about five yards of you all the timeâ€”although you were on the ground with the prosecutor. I could not arrest you in the actâ€”I arrested you in the street about two minutes' walk from your home.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. It was hardly a minute or two from the time I saw the prosecutor on the ground till the man ran awayâ€”it all took place quicklyâ€”in the first instance I was about twenty yards awayâ€”the three prisoners were all together and I was behind the lotâ€”I am certain both women were there.
Cross-examined by Lumley. Two other women were not standing in a gateway across the road while you were talking to some man. '

MATTHEW MASON . I am a fitter of 1. Salop Street Braid's Village. Oldbury, near Dudleyâ€”on November 11th I was looking for lodgings in Londonâ€”I met the two female prisoners and asked them where I could get lodgingsâ€”they said "Come with us and we will show you"â€”I pro
ceeded to go with them when the male prisoner came alongside of me and then got behind mo and put his fingers round my throat and threw me on the ground and said to the women "Have you got his b----ticket?"â€”the women said "No"â€”he then said, "Well have you got his b----money?"â€”I called for help and a policeman came running upâ€”the nun ran awayâ€”my throat has not been right sinceâ€”I was sober.
Cross-examined by Norton. You were not with the women when I first saw youâ€”I was in the women's company about five minutes before 1 saw youâ€”I am sure you are the man.

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. It was one o'clock in the morning and pretty darkâ€”I had never seen the women beforeâ€”I am sure that Blake was one of the two women; she had a red blouse on at the time.
Cross-examined by Lumley. There were no other women with me.
Re-examined. The night after the assault I went to the police station and identified the two female prisoners.
By MR. BURNIE. I went with a police constable to a lodging house where there were thirty or more women and picked out the two female prisonersâ€”Blake who had a red blouse on was with Lumley.

DANIEL TYDEMAN (Detective Inspector M.) On November 11th at 1.30 a.m. Norton was brought to the police station of which I was in chargeâ€”the prosecutor came in at the same timeâ€”he was quite exhausted and covered in dirtâ€”he spoke with the greatest difficultyâ€”I examined his throat and he had discolorations round it which appeared to have been caused by very great violence recently receivedâ€”the constable also was suffering from two very bad wounds on the left knee cap; his trousers were cut right acrossâ€”in consequence of his injuries I called the divisional surgeon in who immediately put him on the sick list and it will be some time before he is well againâ€”from a description of the female prisoners I went with Detective Helson to 99 Mount Street Boroughâ€”I saw the two women amongst a number of others and told them I had suspicion that they were implicated in a case of violenceâ€”the prosecutor had already picked them out as being the two women that had assaulted him just previouslyâ€”Lumley said "I was standing round the corner in Suffolk Street and saw a row. I was talking to a young man. I don't know who the other woman is but she had a red blouse on. I didn't do any-thing. The policeman run after a man and I went in doors"â€”I took both women to the station and they commenced quarrellingâ€”Blake said to Lumley "You saw me there; you had your old ponse with you; you brought me into this"â€”I had Lumley removed to the cellsâ€”Blake said pointing to the prosecutor "That man offered me a shilling and some man came up behind us and got hold of him by the throat and tried to throttle him. I and Barbara were together and I ran for my life"â€”they were chargedâ€”they made another statement to Detective Helsonâ€”I was not present.
Cross-examined by Norton. I say the prosecutor was covered in dirt not mudâ€”when you were brought to the station you were also covered in dirt so was the constable.
Cross-examined by Lumley. Blake was in bed at the lodging houseâ€”you were in the kitchen.

ALBERT HELSON (Detective M.) At about 2.30 a.m. on November 11th on the prosecutor's statement I went with Detective Tydeman to several lodging housesâ€”we called at 99 Mount Street and ascertained that Lumley and Blake had gone in there about 1.30â€”we went in and arrested themâ€”Lumley said "I was standing at the corner"â€”Blake

said "All right"â€”they were chargedâ€”in the dock. Blake said turning to Lumley "Barbara if I live to be 100 years I'll pay you for this: it is all your work: you and your ponse did the job"â€”Lumley replied "What's the use of your saving that? You know as much of the job as I do."

Cross-examined by MR. BURNIE. We had Blake sent for at the lodging house and she came down stairsâ€”the prosecutor stopped outside the roomâ€”when Lumley came out the prosecutor said she was the woman: then Blake came out and the prosecutor said something to Inspector Tydeman.
Cross-examined by Lumley. The prosecutor did not at first say you were not the womenâ€”directly he saw you he said, "That's the woman."
Re-examined. I am positive these are the two women that were shown us that nightâ€”Blake had a red blouse on.

Norton's statement before the Magistrate in the witness box: "On the night of the 10th at the corner of Little Lant Street. Barbara spoke to me. I used to live with her formerly and the prosecutor walked by and two men sprang from a doorway. I ran and heard someone say 'Stop or I will throw this.'I saw it was a policeman. He threw a truncheon which struck a wall and he fell and lay there a minute: then he got up and seized me and we met prosecutor. The policeman said.' Is this him. 'and the prosecutor said' That is one of them that's him.'I was taken to the police station. I am absolutely innocent."'

p.hi: Norton in his defence said he repeated his statement: that he met a young woman whom he formerly knew and that she wanted to know where he lived and as he-did not want her to know he started running away when he heard a voice cry. "Stop or I will throw this stick." And then he was seized; and that he was innocent of the charge.

Lumley in her defence on oath said that at 12.30 on the night in question the prosecutor with two women met her crossing the road: that the women left the man who asked her if she could take him anywhere for the night: that she said No but if he would wait a minaute would sec: that she left him at the corner having recognised someone to whom she went to speak; when two men rushed from a gateway and she saw the prosecutor struggling with them and that she then went indoors and did not remember any more until she was arrested: that Blake was not with them haring said "Good night" and left them.

div1.p: GUILTY .

Blake then
PLEADED GUILTY to a conviction of felony at the North London Sessions on July 22nd 1902. Three other convictions were proved against her. Norton was stated to be an associate of prostitutes and thieves and to have been convicted of living on the proceeds of prostitution. Lumley was stated to have been summarily convicted of assault and to be a violent woman and a great trouble to the police.

NORTONâ€”
Two years' hard labour.
BLAKEâ€”
Eighteen months hard labour.
LUMLEYâ€”
Twelve months' hard labour.
ADJOURNED TO MONDAY JANUARY 11TH, 1904.
